				<article id="post-582" class="group post-container entry-content">

				<header class="index-header">
						<h1 class="index-title">Hm. Looks like something went wrong&hellip;</h1>
				</header>		

			

					<div class="index-content">
						<p>It seems we can’t find what you’re looking for. If you are looking for a specific post, try searching up in the right-hand corner. Otherwise take a look at our most recent posts below.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->

        $(this).parent().attr("title",function(i,val){
            return val == alt ? "" : alt;
        });
    });
});

			<div class="initial-quote">När man som jag är född i en prästgård stiftar man snart bekantskap med djävulen.</div>

					When one is born in a parsonage, as I was, one soon becomes acquainted with the devil. (Swedish) 				</div>

				<h1 class="event-home-title">
					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/more-job-market-successes/" title="More Job Market Successes!" rel="bookmark">	
						More Job Market Successes!					</a>
				</h1>
								
			<p>Scandinavian Department graduate successes on the job market continue&#8230; <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/more-job-market-successes/#more-2021" class="more-link"><span aria-label="Continue reading More Job Market Successes!">(more&hellip;)</span></a></p>
			
			</article><!-- news wrapper -->
					
<article class="home-news-wrapper">
		
				<h1 class="event-home-title">
					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/academic-job-market-successes/" title="Academic Job Market Successes!" rel="bookmark">	
						Academic Job Market Successes!					</a>
				</h1>
								
			<p>It has been a bumper year for graduates and associates of the Scandinavian Department on the job market. Starting new positions this summer are&#8230; <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/academic-job-market-successes/#more-1983" class="more-link"><span aria-label="Continue reading Academic Job Market Successes!">(more&hellip;)</span></a></p>
			
			</article><!-- news wrapper -->
					
<article class="home-news-wrapper">
		
				<h1 class="event-home-title">
					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/summer-awards-for-graduate-study-abroad/" title="Summer Awards for Graduate Study Abroad" rel="bookmark">	
						Summer Awards for Graduate Study Abroad					</a>
				</h1>
								
			<p>Two of our graduate students have won awards to study Scandinavian languages abroad this summer.</p>
<p> <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/summer-awards-for-graduate-study-abroad/#more-1988" class="more-link"><span aria-label="Continue reading Summer Awards for Graduate Study Abroad">(more&hellip;)</span></a></p>
			
			</article><!-- news wrapper -->
					
<article class="home-news-wrapper">
		
				<h1 class="event-home-title">
					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/congratulations-celine/" title="Congratulations, Celine!" rel="bookmark">	
						Congratulations, Celine!					</a>
				</h1>
								
			<p>Celine Vezina, double major in Scandinavian and English, has received a <a href="http://surf.berkeley.edu/">Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship</a>  <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/congratulations-celine/#more-1980" class="more-link"><span aria-label="Continue reading Congratulations, Celine!">(more&hellip;)</span></a></p>
			
			</article><!-- news wrapper -->
					
<article class="home-news-wrapper">
		
				<h1 class="event-home-title">
					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/1975-2/" title="Mark Sandberg presents &#8220;Ibsen&#8217;s Houses&#8221; in New York" rel="bookmark">	
						Mark Sandberg presents &#8220;Ibsen&#8217;s Houses&#8221; in New York					</a>
				</h1>
								<figure class="news-home-thumb">
				<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/1975-2/" title="Mark Sandberg presents &#8220;Ibsen&#8217;s Houses&#8221; in New York" rel="bookmark">
					<img width="100" height="151" src="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/978110703392401-100x151.jpg" class="attachment-news size-news wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/978110703392401-100x151.jpg 100w, http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/978110703392401-199x300.jpg 199w, http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/978110703392401.jpg 429w" sizes="(max-width: 100px) 100vw, 100px" />				</a>
			</figure>
						
			<p><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/mark-sandberg/">Mark Sandberg</a>, Professor of Norwegian and Film and Media, recently gave a talk on his new book, <i>Ibsen&#8217;s Houses: Architectural Metaphor and the Modern Uncanny</i>, at <a href="http://www.tfana.org/">Theatre for a New Audience</a> in Brooklyn, New York.</p>
<p> <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/1975-2/#more-1975" class="more-link"><span aria-label="Continue reading Mark Sandberg presents &#8220;Ibsen&#8217;s Houses&#8221; in New York">(more&hellip;)</span></a></p>
			
			</article><!-- news wrapper -->
					
<article class="home-news-wrapper">
		
				<h1 class="event-home-title">
					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/congratulations-class-of-2017/" title="Congratulations, Class of 2017!" rel="bookmark">	
						Congratulations, Class of 2017!					</a>
				</h1>
								
			<p>On May 15, the Scandinavian Department celebrated Commencement for 2017. <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/congratulations-class-of-2017/#more-1971" class="more-link"><span aria-label="Continue reading Congratulations, Class of 2017!">(more&hellip;)</span></a></p>
			
			</article><!-- news wrapper -->
					
<article class="home-news-wrapper">
		
				<h1 class="event-home-title">
					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/2016-17-outstanding-gsi-ida-johnson/" title="2016-17 Outstanding GSI: Ida Johnson" rel="bookmark">	
						2016-17 Outstanding GSI: Ida Johnson					</a>
				</h1>
								<figure class="news-home-thumb">
				<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/2016-17-outstanding-gsi-ida-johnson/" title="2016-17 Outstanding GSI: Ida Johnson" rel="bookmark">
					<img width="100" height="144" src="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/Ida-Johnson-100x144.jpg" class="attachment-news size-news wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/Ida-Johnson-100x144.jpg 100w, http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/Ida-Johnson.jpg 151w" sizes="(max-width: 100px) 100vw, 100px" />				</a>
			</figure>
						
			<p><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/ida-moen-johnson/">Ida Moen Johnson</a> is the winner of the Outstanding GSI Award for 2016 for her work in teaching Norwegian.  <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/2016-17-outstanding-gsi-ida-johnson/#more-1969" class="more-link"><span aria-label="Continue reading 2016-17 Outstanding GSI: Ida Johnson">(more&hellip;)</span></a></p>
			
			</article><!-- news wrapper -->

				</h1>

<div class="m_-9062562435121276995gmail_msg"></div>
<p> <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/scandinavian-198-a-danish-guide-to-happiness/#more-1828" class="more-link"><span aria-label="Continue reading New DeCal! &#8220;A Danish Guide to Happiness&#8221;">(more&hellip;)</span></a></p>

<article id="post-1983" class="group wide-side-post-container">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="welcome-title">Academic Job Market Successes!</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="welcome-content">
	
	    
	
		<p>It has been a bumper year for graduates and associates of the Scandinavian Department on the job market. Starting new positions this summer are&#8230;<span id="more-1983"></span></p>
<p><img class="wp-image-244 alignleft" src="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/Benjamin-Bigelow.jpg" alt="" width="103" height="149" srcset="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/Benjamin-Bigelow.jpg 151w, http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/Benjamin-Bigelow-100x144.jpg 100w" sizes="(max-width: 103px) 100vw, 103px" /><strong>Ben Bigelow</strong> (Ph.D. 2017) as Assistant Professor of Scandinavian Studies in the Department of German, Scandinavian, and Dutch at the University of Minnesota &#8211; Twin Cities in Minneapolis.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><img class="wp-image-228 alignright" src="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/Verenacolor.jpg" alt="" width="125" height="139" srcset="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/Verenacolor.jpg 196w, http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/Verenacolor-100x111.jpg 100w" sizes="(max-width: 125px) 100vw, 125px" /><strong>Verena Hoefig</strong> (Ph.D. 2014) as Assistant Professor of Medieval Studies in the Department of Germanic Languages and Literatures at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><img class="wp-image-1230 alignleft" src="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/Crawford-12-1.jpg" alt="" width="156" height="174" srcset="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/Crawford-12-1.jpg 196w, http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/Crawford-12-1-100x111.jpg 100w" sizes="(max-width: 156px) 100vw, 156px" />Lecturer in Scandinavian <strong><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/jackson-crawford-2/">Jackson Crawford</a> </strong>has won a permanent position as Instructor of Nordic Studies and Nordic Program Coordinator, Department of Germanic and Slavic Languages and Literatures at the University of Colorado, Boulder.</p>
<p>Congratulations, Ben, Verena, and Jackson!</p>
	</div><!-- .welcome-content -->

</article><!-- #post-1983 -->

        $(this).parent().attr("title",function(i,val){
            return val == alt ? "" : alt;
        });
    });
});
</script>

<header id="site-header" class="home wideness" role="banner">
		<div class="upper-field">
		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Året har 16 måneder: november<br />
december, januar, februar, marts, april<br />
maj, juni, juli, august, september<br />
oktober, november, november, november, november.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					The year has 16 months: November<br />
December, January, February, March, April<br />
May, June, July, August, September<br />
October, November, November, November, November. (Danish)				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Henrik Nordbrandt</span>
				
			</a>
			
									 
	
	
	</div>

		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Dumheten overlever alltid. Den er så og si for dum til å dø.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					Stupidity will always survive. It is so to speak too dumb to die. (Norwegian)				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Aksel Sandemose</span>
				
			</a>

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>

<header id="site-header" class="home wideness" role="banner">
	<div class="upper-field">
		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Kultur är motstånd.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					Culture is resistance. (Swedish) 				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Kerstin Ekman</span>
				
			</a>
			
									 
	
	
	</div>

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. 	<div class="upper-field">
		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Bera kvað Egil vera víkingsefni.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					Bera said that Egill had the makings of a viking. (Old Norse) 				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Egils saga, chap. 40</span>
				
			</a>

			<div class="site-header-content">

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. <header id="site-header" class="home wideness" role="banner">
	<div class="upper-field">
		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Dumheten overlever alltid. Den er så og si for dum til å dø.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					Stupidity will always survive. It is so to speak too dumb to die. (Norwegian)				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Aksel Sandemose</span>
				
			</a>
			
									 
	
	
	</div>
	
			<div class="site-header-content">
	 <h1><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu">  Course Language  Old Norse</a></h1>

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. <header id="site-header" class="home wideness" role="banner">
	<div class="upper-field">
		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Om du inte känner till namnen försvinner också din kunskap om tingen.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					If you don't know their names, things will soon fade from memory. (Swedish) 				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Carl af Linné/Linnaeus</span>
				
			</a>
			
									 
	
	
	</div>

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. <header id="site-header" class="home wideness" role="banner">
	<div class="upper-field">
		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Hvis jeg visste hva som var meningen med livet, trengte jeg ikke å skrive. Da kunne jeg bare sitte og vite.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					If I knew the meaning of life, I wouldn’t need to write—I could just sit around knowing it. (Norwegian)				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Erlend Loe</span>
				
			</a>
			
									 
	
	
	</div>
	
			<div class="site-header-content">

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>

	<div class="upper-field">
		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Två ting äro vita: oskuld -- arsenik.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					Two things are white: innocence -- arsenic. (Swedish) 				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - C.J.L. Almqvist</span>
				
			</a>

				</p>

								
					<p><i></i></p>
												
					<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 3</span></p>					
						</div><!-- .entry-content -->

					</article><!-- #post-1713 -->
	
					
					<article id="post-1714" class="group index-post-container course-list-wrapper">
						<header class="index-header">
							<h1 class="course-title">
			<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses/teaching-methodology-reading-composition-4/" title="Permalink to Teaching Methodology: Reading &amp; Composition" rel="bookmark">	
				SCANDINAVIAN 301, Section 2: Teaching Methodology: Reading &amp; Composition			</a>
		</h1>
	
						</header><!-- .entry-header -->

						<div class="index-content">
						
								<p class="section-spacing">
								TuTh 8-9:30, 6408 Dwinelle. 				
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/jonas-wellendorf/">Jonas Wellendorf</a></b>

																 
				</p>

								
					<p><i></i></p>
												
					<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 3</span></p>					
						</div><!-- .entry-content -->

					</article><!-- #post-1714 -->
	
															
										
										
			</div>
		</section><!-- #content-container -->

		</div>

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>

				<a name="randc"></a>

			
						
								<h2 class="course-level-header">Reading and Composition Courses</h2>
		<div class="undergraduate-courses">
				
					<article id="post-1815" class="group index-post-container course-list-wrapper">
						<header class="index-header">
							<h1 class="course-title">
			<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses/session-a-may-22-june-30-reading-composition/" title="Permalink to Session A (May 22-June 30): The Nordic Child" rel="bookmark">	
				SCANDINAVIAN R5B, Section 1: Session A (May 22-June 30): The Nordic Child			</a>
		</h1>
	
						</header><!-- .entry-header -->

						<div class="index-content">
						
								<p class="section-spacing">
								TuWTh 1-3:30, 206 Dwinelle. 				
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/ida-moen-johnson/">Ida Moen Johnson</a></b>

																 
				</p>
												
					<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span></p>
						</div><!-- .entry-content -->
					</article><!-- #post-1815 -->
	
					
					<article id="post-1817" class="group index-post-container course-list-wrapper">
						<header class="index-header">
							<h1 class="course-title">
			<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses/session-c-june-19-august-11-reading-composition/" title="Permalink to Session C (June 19-August 11): Into the Woods: The Forest in Scandinavian Literature" rel="bookmark">	
				SCANDINAVIAN R5B, Section 101: Session C (June 19-August 11): Into the Woods: The Forest in Scandinavian Literature			</a>
		</h1>
	
						</header><!-- .entry-header -->

						<div class="index-content">
						
								<p class="section-spacing">
								TuWTh 12-2, 254 Dwinelle. 				
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/jenna-coughlin/">Jenna Coughlin</a></b>

																 
				</p>
												
					<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span></p>
						</div><!-- .entry-content -->
					</article><!-- #post-1817 -->
	
					
					<article id="post-1818" class="group index-post-container course-list-wrapper">
						<header class="index-header">
							<h1 class="course-title">

<article id="post-1879" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Courses for Non-UC Berkeley Students</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<div class="index-content">
<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
<p><strong>During the Summer</strong></p>
<p>Our summer courses are generally open for registration by anyone — not just UC Berkeley students.  We offer a variety of language and culture courses each summer, taught by qualified UCB instructors.  All summer course registration goes through the Berkeley Summer Sessions office, whose <a href="http://summer.berkeley.edu">website</a> outlines the enrollment process, tuition fees, and more.</p>
<p><strong>During the Academic Year</strong></p>
<p>While we are unable to offer traditional “auditing” or “sitting in on” a Fall or Spring course, the UC Extension makes it possible for non-UC Berkeley students to enroll in UC Berkeley classes through their <a href="http://extension.berkeley.edu/static/studentservices/concurrent/">Concurrent Enrollment</a> program, pending instructor approval.</p>
<p>Courses through Concurrent Enrollment can be taken for credit/letter grade, pass/no pass, or no credit; registration costs vary depending on the grading option.  For details on Concurrent Enrollment requirements, deadlines, applications and fees, please visit <a href="http://extension.berkeley.edu/static/studentservices/concurrent/">their website</a> or call 510-642-4111.</p>
<p>For registration purposes, you will need the class number from UC Berkeley’s official <a href="http://schedule.berkeley.edu/%20">online schedule of classes</a>.</p>
<p>A few weeks before the class begins, it is important that the potential Concurrent Enrollment student e-mails the instructor of the course to introduce him or herself and informs the instructor of his or her plans.  Course descriptions with instructor names are posted in the Courses section of this website.  To contact our instructors, please see the <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people-category/permanent-faculty/">People</a> page of this website.</p>
</div>
<p>If you are interested in a language course, especially if you are unsure which level is right for you, please contact language coordinator <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/karen-moller">Karen Moller</a>. For more information, see the <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/languages/">Languages</a> section of this website, and select your desired language from the menu on the left.</p>
<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
<p>In general, applications for Concurrent Enrollment are not officially approved and signed by the instructor until the first week of class, as part of the approval is based on the number of spaces available.  Once approved by the instructor, the application will go through an approval process between the Berkeley campus and the Concurrent Enrollment office, and finally the student will be officially enrolled and billed by the UC Extension.</p>
</div>
</div>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-1879 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>

</ul></div>		</div><!-- #secondary .widget-area -->


			
				
<article id="post-1921" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN R5B, Section 1: A Ring of Retelling: The Romanticized Nordic Legend</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			MWF 8-9 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 183 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/adam-j-carl/">Adam J. Carl</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>This course satisfies the second half or the &#8220;B&#8221; portion of the Reading and Composition requirement. </strong></p>
<p>The stories told through the Viking Age and Medieval Norse literature have directly influenced and inspired the lore in modern works like <em>The Hobbit, A Song of Ice and Fire</em>, and Marvel Comic’s <em>Thor</em>. One Scandinavian legend in particular has captured popular imagination across the world: the legend of <em>The</em> <em>Saga of the Vǫlsungs</em>. The saga – rife with curses, warring kingdoms, love triangles, and (of course) dragons – has been retold over and over. Authors, screenwriters, and composers simply can’t resist a good dragon-slaying.</p>
<p>Our reading list will sketch a genealogy of literature which cuts across national borders and historical eras. Retellings of <em>The Saga of the Vǫlsungs</em> are authored by familiar names, like JRR Tolkien and Richard Wagner. Some versions are by famous Scandinavian authors like Henrik Ibsen (sometimes called Norway’s Shakespeare) and Selma Lagerlöf (the first woman to receive a Nobel Prize in literature). The retellings encountered in this course are hardly tired old tropes; they are moments of creativity for some of the Modern era’s most successful authors.</p>
<p>In this composition course, we will investigate the interplay between the content of writing and the stylistic/technical aspects. The course theme of “retelling” will help to highlight the contexts of historical writing and our own moment in history. We will attempt to move questions from “How is this different?” towards “Why is this different?” Along the way, the class will discover the rich cultural heritage of Scandinavia, and how a retelling of an old Viking legend can lead to the next Hollywood blockbuster or best-selling comic book.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong></p>
<p><em>Saga of the Volsungs </em>translated by Jesse Byock 978-0140447385 (~70 pages / $10)</p>
<p><em> Wagner’s Ring in 1848</em> by Edward R. Haymes 978-1571139320 (83 pages / $28)</p>
<p><em> The Treasure</em> (<em>Herr Arnes Penningar</em>) by Selma Lagerlöf 978-1434458254 (60 pages / $6)</p>
<p>Ibsen’s <em>The Vikings at Helgeland </em>978-1420930849 (84 pages $10)</p>
<p><em>The Hobbit</em> by JRR Tolkien 978-0547928227 (273 pages / $10)</p>
<p>Other readings will be made available in a course reader or through bCourses.</p>
<p>$78 total from Amazon</p>
<p>40 pages per week = 630 pages as target total course reading –</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong>  Successful completion of the “A” portion of the Reading &amp; Composition requirement or its equivalent.  Students may not enroll in nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1921 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1537" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">DANISH 1B: Beginning Danish II</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			TuTh 2-3:30 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2017</a>, B33B Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/karen-moller/">Karen Møller</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Students will further develop the basic elements of communicative competence in both spoken and written Danish within a cultural context.</p>
<p>Students an average state their workload in this class is 3-5 hours outside class. Students will be expected to participate in assigned online projects.</p>
<p>Textbook: <em>Sådan 2</em>, Pihl Helleland and Hansen, Gyldendal, ISBN 978870214460</p>
<p>Prerequisites: Danish 1A or an equivalent course with a passing grade, plus consent by instructor.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1537 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

		<div id="footer-content">
			
			<div class="footer-nav">

<li id="menu-item-1635" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1635"><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/">Programs</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1562" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1562"><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people-category/permanent-faculty/">People</a></li>

<article id="post-1913" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">DANISH 1A: Beginning Danish</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			TuTh 2-3:30 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, B33B Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/karen-moller/">Karen Møller</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>(Fall only. Danish 1B is offered in Spring.) Classes meet for three hours of Danish instruction per week. Students will acquire basic communicative competence in all four foreign language skills (speaking, listening, reading and writing) within a cultural context.</p>
<p>More details about this language <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/languages/danish/">here</a>.</p>
<p><b>Workload:</b> About five hours of work outside of class per week (includes online homework), an oral and written midterm and final.</p>
<p><b>Text</b>: RIGTIG DANSK, Karen Christensen Bahamondes, Gyldendal, 2015.</p>
<p><b>Prerequisites:</b>  None. Elementary Danish is open to all students without prior knowledge of Danish. <b>The course is not open to native, near-native, or heritage speakers of any Nordic language.</b> Course cannot be repeated without <em>prior consent</em> from the language coordinator.</p>
<p><b>THIS COURSE IS ALSO OFFERED AS A DISTANCE LEARNING CLASS FOR STUDENTS AT OTHER UC CAMPUSES. COURSE HAS A DELAYED START: LAST WEEK OF SEPTEMBER 2017. PLEASE CONTACT THE INSTRUCTOR FOR FURTHER INFORMATION.</b></p>
<p>If you are not a currently registered student, you may be able to enroll via <a href="http://extension.berkeley.edu/static/studentservices/concurrent/">Concurrent Enrollment, UC Berkeley Extension</a>. Please note that the Concurrent Enrollment application must be approved by the department. Approval is based on availability of space in the class; enrolled UC students on a waitlist have priority.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1913 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

		<div id="footer-content">
			
			<div class="footer-nav">
				<div class="menu-footer-menu-container"><ul id="menu-footer-menu" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1584" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-home menu-item-1584"><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/">Home</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1635" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1635"><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/">Programs</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1562" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1562"><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people-category/permanent-faculty/">People</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1951" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-1951"><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1587" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1587"><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/history/">Resources</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1586" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1586"><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/opportunities/">Opportunities</a></li>

		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Hvis jeg visste hva som var meningen med livet, trengte jeg ikke å skrive. Da kunne jeg bare sitte og vite.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					If I knew the meaning of life, I wouldn’t need to write—I could just sit around knowing it. (Norwegian)				</div>

<article id="post-1914" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">FINNISH 1A: Beginning Finnish</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			MWF 9-10 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, B33B Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/lotta-weckstrom/">Lotta Weckström</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>(Fall only. Finnish 1B is offered in Spring.) Classes meet for three hours of Finnish instruction per week. Students will acquire basic communicative competence in all four foreign language skills (speaking, listening, reading and writing) within a cultural context.  Click <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/languages/finnish/">here</a> for more information about Finnish.</p>
<p>More details about this language <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/languages/finnish/">here</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Workload: </strong> About five hours of work outside of class per week, an oral and written midterm and final.</p>
<p><strong>Texts: </strong><br />
Sonja Gehring and Sanni Heinzmann:<br />
<em>Suomen mestari 1. Suomen oppikirja aikuisille</em><br />
Second edition, 2011. Finn Lectura. ISBN 9789517924368</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong>  None. Elementary Finnish is open to students without prior knowledge of Finnish. <strong>However, the course is open to native, near-native, or heritage speakers of <u>ANY </u>OTHER Nordic language.</strong> Course cannot be repeated without <em>prior consent</em> from the language coordinator.</p>
<p>If you are not a currently registered student, you may be able to enroll via <a href="http://extension.berkeley.edu/static/studentservices/concurrent/">Concurrent Enrollment, UC Berkeley Extension</a>. Please note that the Concurrent Enrollment application must be approved by the department. Approval is based on availability of space in the class; enrolled UC students on a waitlist have priority.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1914 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

<li id="menu-item-1635" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1635"><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/">Programs</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1562" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1562"><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people-category/permanent-faculty/">People</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1951" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-category menu-item-1951"><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/">Courses</a></li>

<article id="post-1533" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">ICELANDIC 1B: Beginning Modern Icelandic</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			MWF 11-12 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2017</a>, 6415 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/jackson-crawford-2/">Jackson Crawford</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Velkomin! Modern Icelandic is the language spoken by the 300,000+ inhabitants of Iceland, a volcanic island in the middle of the North Atlantic. Iceland was settled by Viking-era settlers from Scandinavia and their slaves, who arrived from Scandinavia and the Scandinavian colonies in Great Britain and Ireland. These Vikings colonized Iceland and Greenland and, briefly, North America. While Icelandic is a Scandinavian language, closely related to Danish, Norwegian, and Swedish, the remote location of the island and the pride that Icelanders have historically taken in their language has kept the changes in the language to a minimum since the Viking Age. This means that Icelandic has a more complicated structure than other Scandinavian languages, but it also means that learning Modern Icelandic makes it easier to learn to read Old Norse, the language of the sagas, poetry, and mythology recorded during the medieval period.</p>
<p><strong>Learning Outcomes:</strong><br />
The goal for the first year will be to comprehend spoken and written Icelandic relating to familiar, everyday topics, and to speak and write Icelandic well enough to satisfy immediate needs. In the second semester we will continue to focus on developing more advanced grammar skills, as well as readiness for basic social situations and common needs, while working on more fluent speaking and writing.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong></p>
<p>(None as such; written materials provided by instructor)</p>
<p>Course Requirements<br />
Homework/Attendance: 15%<br />
Quizzes: 10%<br />
Exams: 25%<br />
Final Exam: 25%<br />
Oral Exams: 10%<br />
Compositions: 15%</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> Icelandic 1A.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1533 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>

<article id="post-1915" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">NORWEGIAN 1A: Beginning Norwegian</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			MWF 9-10 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 104 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/jenna-coughlin/">Jenna Coughlin</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>(Fall only.  Norwegian 1B is offered in Spring.) Classes meet for three hours of instruction per week.  Students will acquire basic communicative competence in all four foreign language skills (speaking, listening, reading and writing) within a cultural context.</p>
<p>More details about this language <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/languages/norwegian/">here</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Workload:</strong> About five hours of work outside of class per week, an oral and written midterm and final.</p>
<p><strong>Text:</strong> <em>Sett i gang 1 </em>(Aarsvold and Lie) t<strong>o be ordered on Amazon Instructions will be given by the instructor at the beginning of the semester.</strong></p>
<p><strong> Prerequisites:</strong>  None. Elementary Norwegian is open to students without prior knowledge of Norwegian. <strong>The course is not open to native, near-native, or heritage speakers of any Nordic language.</strong> Course cannot be repeated without <em>prior consent</em> from the language coordinator.</p>
<p>If you are not a currently registered student, you may be able to enroll via <a href="http://extension.berkeley.edu/static/studentservices/concurrent/">Concurrent Enrollment, UC Berkeley Extension</a>. Please note that the Concurrent Enrollment application must be approved by the department. Approval is based on availability of space in the class; enrolled UC students on a waitlist have priority.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1915 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>

	<div class="upper-field">
		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Valr lá þar á sandi<br />
vitinn inum eineygja<br />
Friggjar faðmbyggvi;<br />
fǫgnuðum dáð slíkri.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					The slain lay there on the sand,<br />
dedicated to the one-eyed<br />
embrace-occupier of Frigg;<br />
we welcomed such doings. <br />
(Old Norse)				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Hrafnsmál, Stanza 12</span>
				
			</a>
			
									 
	
	
	</div>

<article id="post-1539" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">NORWEGIAN 1B: Beginning Norwegian II</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			MWF 9-10 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2017</a>, 104 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/ida-moen-johnson/">Ida Moen Johnson</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Students will further develop the basic elements of communicative competence in both spoken and written Norwegian within a cultural context.</p>
<p>Students on average state their outside class workload to be 3 hours.</p>
<p>Textbook: <em>Sett i gang</em></p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> Norwegian 1A or an equivalent course with a passing grade, plus consent by instructor.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1539 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

	<div class="upper-field">
		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Orkesteret er for stort for os. Og vi sidder midt inde i det. Vi får ikke sammenhængen. Instrumenterne er for lige ind på os.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					The orchestra is too big for us. And we sit right in the middle of it; we can't grasp the context. The Instruments are too tight up against us. 				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Sigbjørn Obstfelder</span>
				
			</a>

<article id="post-1916" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SWEDISH 1A: Beginning Swedish</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			MWF 9-10 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 228 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/zachary-blinkinsop-2/">Zachary Blinkinsop</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>(Fall only.  Swedish 1B is offered in Spring.) Classes meet for three hours of instruction per week.  Students will acquire basic communicative competence in all four foreign language skills (speaking, listening, reading and writing) within a cultural context.</p>
<p>More details about this language <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/languages/swedish/">here</a>.</p>
<p><strong> Workload:</strong> About five hours of work outside of class per week, an oral and written midterm and final.</p>
<p><strong>Text:</strong>  <em>Rivstart A1 + A2 </em>(There is a textbook <strong>and</strong> exercise book)</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong>  None. Elementary Swedish is open to students without prior knowledge of Swedish. <strong>The course is not open to native, near-native, or heritage speakers of any Nordic language.</strong> Course cannot be repeated without <em>prior consent</em> from the language coordinator.</p>
<p>If you are not a currently registered student, you may be able to enroll via <a href="http://extension.berkeley.edu/static/studentservices/concurrent/">Concurrent Enrollment, UC Berkeley Extension</a>. Please note that the Concurrent Enrollment application must be approved by the department. Approval is based on availability of space in the class; enrolled UC students on a waitlist have priority.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1916 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1540" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SWEDISH 1B: Beginning Swedish II</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			MWF 9-10 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2017</a>, 250 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/christian-gullette/">Christian Gullette</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Students will further develop the basic elements of communicative competence in both spoken and written Swedish within a cultural context.</p>
<p>Students on average state their outside class workload to be 3 hours.</p>
<p><strong>Textbook:</strong> <em>Rivstart</em></p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> Swedish 1A or an equivalent course with a passing grade, plus consent by instructor.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1540 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1928" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 115: Contemporary Film and Television in the Global North</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			TuTh 12:30-2 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 188 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/mark-sandberg/">Mark Sandberg</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>L&amp;S Breadth: </strong> Arts &amp; Literature<br />
<strong>Cross-listed with Film 160, Section 2.<br />
Enrollment in Scandinavian 115 will count as equivalent to Film 160, Section 2 for the purposes of the Film major. </strong></p>
<p>Recent television production in the Nordic countries has reached a new global audience outside the media circuits (such as art-house cinema) that historically have been the more typical Nordic outlets to international markets. Successful branding of some content as “Nordic Noir” and the radical reorganization of the distribution model for international television have allowed more mainstream circulation of television content abroad, reaching a wider audience than the earlier niche appeals of Dogme 95 filmmaking, the art films of Bergman, Dreyer, and von Trier, or the “Swedish New Wave” of the 1960s. How have contemporary Nordic television series (in both Nordic Noir and other modes) created these new forms of appeal? To what degree do they form an alternative to the contemporary American practices of television production, and as a consequence, what do current Nordic television series tell us about today’s cultural configurations in the global North?</p>
<p>To understand these questions, this course takes the idea of the “remake” as a diagnostic tool for examining for investigating the border zones between cultures. The examples range from direct, almost slavish remakes to looser forms of inspiration, but in every case a Nordic television show will be paired with a US or UK comparison piece to ask questions about cultural adaptation and translation. The course looks at this extensive “version-making” activity in order to answer questions such as: why are so many successful Nordic TV series be remade in English (and how are American and British audiences different in this regard)? What constitutes local color? What are the mechanisms of cultural and linguistic translation that allow shows to flow from a native context to a more global audience? What does one get out of watching an original that differs from watching a remake? Is one inherently better than the other?</p>
<p>Examples investigated will include multiple episodes of television series from Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Great Britain, and the U.S., presented in these configurations: <em>Riget</em>/<em>Kingdom Hospital</em>; <em>Henning Mankells Walllander/Wallander</em>; <em>Forbrydelsen/The Killing</em>; <em>Bron-Broen/The Bridge/The Tunnel</em>; <em>West Wing/Borgen</em>; <em>Äkta människor</em>/<em>Humans</em>; <em>Okkupert/Man in the High Castle</em>; and <em>Skam</em>.</p>
<p>There are no prerequisite courses for this upper-division elective, and all materials will be either in English or in subtitled versions: no knowledge of any of the Nordic languages is required. Format of presentation will be a mixture of lecture and discussion.</p>
<p>Short readings (academic articles and journalistic discussions of various shows) will be made available on bCourses. There are no required textbooks.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1928 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1933" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 220: Early Scandinavian Literature: Eddic Poetry</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			Th 10-1 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 6415 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/kate-heslop/">Kate Heslop</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>With the recent publication of a new edition of the eddic corpus (<em>Eddukvæði</em>, ed. Jonas Kristjánsson and Vésteinn Ólason, Reykjavik, 2014), a comprehensive study of eddic metrics (<em>The meters of Old Norse eddic poetry</em>, Seiichi Suzuki, Berlin, 2014) and a handbook (<em>A handbook to eddic poetry</em>, ed. Carolyne Larrington et al., Cambridge, 2016), the time is ripe for a reconsideration of this fascinating material. In this seminar we will read, discuss and write about poetry in eddic meters, focusing in particular on the poetry of the Codex Regius manuscript (Gks 2365 4to). In particular, seminar participants can expect to:</p>
<p>work closely with the Codex Regius manuscript (in facsimile) as well as other important manuscript sources (versions of <em>Vǫluspá</em>, quotations from eddic mythological poetry in <em>Gylfaginning</em>, eddic heroic poetry in <em>fornaldarsögur</em>);</p>
<p>get to know the various editions of eddic poetry, and familiarize themselves with their advantages and disadvantages;</p>
<p>get a basic grounding in eddic metrics – useful for comparative work with other parts of the Germanic alliterative tradition, as well as the best starting point for understanding skaldic metrics;</p>
<p>and discuss issues in eddic scholarship, both historical and more recent.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong></p>
<p>Larrington, C., Quinn, J. and Schorn, B. (eds.) (2016) <em>A Handbook to Eddic Poetry: Myths and Legends of Early Scandinavia</em>. Cambridge: Cambridge UP, 2016.</p>
<p>ISBN: 9781107135444.</p>
<p>NB: the full text of this book is available for on-campus download via oskicat.</p>
<p>Jun Terasawa (2011) <em>Old English Metre: An Introduction</em>. Toronto: University of Toronto Press. ISBN: 9781442611290.</p>
<p>Additional texts will be supplied on bcourses.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> At least one semester of Old Norse language, or consent of instructor.</p>
<p><strong>Workload:</strong> each session will include a short informal presentation of class material by one or more course participants.</p>
<p>Final research paper (20-25 pg.), due at end of semester.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:  </strong>Graduate standing; consent of instructor.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1933 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<header id="site-header" class="home wideness" role="banner">
	<div class="upper-field">
		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Þat eru bókrúnar, <br />
þat eru bjargrúnar,<br />
ok allar ǫlrúnar,<br />
ok mætar meginrúnar.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					That is book-runes, <br />
that is birth-runes, <br />
and all ale-runes, <br />
and the famed power-runes.<br />
(Old Norse)				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Sigrdrífumál, stanza 19</span>
				
			</a>
			
									 
	
	
	</div>

<article id="post-1716" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 220: Early Scandinavian Literature: Old Norse Mythology and Theories of Myth</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			F 12-3 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2017</a>, 6415 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/jonas-wellendorf/">Jonas Wellendorf</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Theorists of myth and mythology rarely draw on Old Norse materials and scholarship on Old Norse myth is often carried out without reference to other mythologies. Nevertheless, a number of influential applications of structuralist, ritualists and ideological approaches to Norse myth can be found. In this seminar, we will study these applications and seek apply to some of the major theories of myth and mythology of the twentieth and twenty-first centuries to the Old Norse mythological primary sources. The aim will be to see what kinds of answers they can give to questions of origin, subject matter and function of Norse myths.</p>
<p>In addition to primary sources and specialized scholarship on Old Norse myth, readings will include works by Dumézil, Dundes, Eliade, Girard, Lévi-Strauss, Lincoln, Malinowski, and others.</p>
<p><strong>Texts: </strong>The <em>Prose Edda</em>, The mythological poems of the <em>Poetic Edda</em>. Both will be read in Old Norse. Secondary readings will primarily be in English.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> At least two semesters of Old Norse language studies (or equivalent).</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1716 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1918" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN R5A, Section 2: Ghost Stories in Medieval and Modern Scandinavia</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			MWF 8-9 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 179 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/isobel-boles/">Isobel Boles</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>This course satisfies the first half or the “A” portion of the Reading and Composition requirement.  </strong></p>
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p>This course will examine the various ghosts of Scandinavian narratives and traditions, from <em>draugar,</em> who creep from burial mounds or restlessly roam the sea, to spirits bound to haunt inhabited dwellings. We will move from otherworldly encounters in excerpts from medieval sagas and poems, to instances of ghostly figures in preserved folklore. The second portion of the course will focus on the ghosts of modern literature, symbolic, gothic, or otherwise, in works of Henrik Ibsen, August Strindberg, Karen Blixen, and Selma Lagerlöf. We will end with a look at trends in contemporary fiction involving ghosts as characters or narrators, including links between spirits of the departed and the genre of crime fiction.</p>
<p>Students will work on developing their critical reading and writing skills by analyzing central themes and questions. We will explore what is unique and universal in the Scandinavian ghost; the degree to which horror and the uncanny are combined with comfort, memory, and connections to family and the past in these figures; and the types of places and circumstances that are likely to give rise to ghosts or ghost stories.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong></p>
<p><strong> </strong>Course Reader and readings on bCourses</p>
<p><em>The Treasure</em>, (<em>Herr Arnes Penningar</em>) by Selma Lagerlöf. 978-1406934878</p>
<p><em>The Elements of Style, 4<sup>th</sup> Edition</em> by William Strunk Jr &amp; E B White. 978-0205309023</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong>  Successful completion of the UC Entry Level Writing Requirement or its equivalent.  <strong>Students may not enroll in nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</strong></p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1918 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1535" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 60: Heroic Legends of the North</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			TuTh 2-3:30 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2017</a>, 242 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/kate-heslop/">Kate Heslop</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong><em>L&amp;S Breadth: Arts &amp; Literature</em></strong></p>
<p><strong>Scandinavian 60 is a requirement for the five major concentrations in Scandinavian.</strong></p>
<p>What is a hero? What use were stories about heroes to the societies that produced them? What is the relationship between heroes and gods (pagan and Christian)? Does heroic narrative preserve memories of historical events? Can monsters or women be heroes? How do heroes die, and why do their stories enjoy such a long – if not altogether blameless – afterlife?</p>
<p>Such questions guide our engagement in this course with the heroic narratives of the premodern North (c. 800-1300). This was a period of radical cultural, social and religious change in Scandinavia, from the pagan warrior societies of the Viking Age to the Christian, literate, centralized world of the Middle Ages. The course centers on the <em>Poetic Edda</em>, a unique medieval collection of mythological and heroic poetry whose roots reach into the Viking Age, and perhaps still further back. But we will also explore other manifestations of the northern fascination with heroes, covering topics such as the oral transmission of heroic narrative; heroes in visual culture (runestones, sculpture, jewellery); Latin-speaking Norse heroes in Saxo grammaticus’<em> Gesta danorum</em> (<em>History of the Danes</em>); how the heroic ethos plays out in more realistic saga genres; and the late medieval flowering of heroic narrative in the romances. A look at the post-medieval reception of heroic legend, for example in contemporary media (e.g. the works of J.R.R. Tolkien, <em>Game of Thrones</em>, video games) and political discourse, rounds off the course.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong></p>
<p><em>The saga of Grettir the strong</em>, trans. by Bernard Scudder (Penguin, 2005). ISBN 978-0140447736.</p>
<p><em>The Poetic Edda</em>, trans. by Carolyne Larrington, revised edition (OUP: 2014). ISBN 978-0199675340.</p>
<p><em>The Saga of the Volsungs</em>, trans. by Jesse Byock (Penguin: 2000). ISBN 978-0140447385.</p>
<p><em>The Sagas of Ragnar Lodbrok</em>, trans. by Ben Waggoner (Troth: 2009). ISBN 978-0578021386.</p>
<p>Additional texts will be made available in a Course Reader.</p>
<p><strong>Course aims</strong>:</p>
<ul>
<li>overview of Scandinavian heroic legend and in-depth knowledge of its two key genres, eddic poetry and the saga;</li>
<li>acquaintance with the material, historical and cultural contexts of Scandinavian heroic legend, both in Viking and medieval Scandinavia and as a wider European phenomenon;</li>
<li>skills in reading and interpreting medieval texts.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Calculation of final grade</strong><br />
Class participation: 10%<br />
Midterm: 10%<br />
Term paper draft (min. 2 pages): 10%<br />
Term paper: 40%<br />
Final exam: 30%</p>
<p>Workload comprises:</p>
<p>brief in-class presentations of set readings; a midterm test (short answer questions plus text analysis); a term paper (5-6 pages on a set question) preceded by a 2-page graded draft; and a final exam (text analysis plus essay questions).</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> none.  The course and readings are in English.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1535 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<link rel='dns-prefetch' href='//scandinavian.berkeley.edu' />

<article id="post-1927" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 101A: Introduction to Old Norse I</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			MWF 12-1 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 33 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/jonas-wellendorf/">Jonas Wellendorf</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>L&amp;S Breadth:</strong>  Arts &amp; Literature</p>
<p>(Fall only. Old Norse 101B is offered in the Spring.)</p>
<p>This class will introduce students to the written vernacular language of Iceland and Norway in the Middle Ages. Class time will focus on the grammatical structure of Old Norse, translating into English, and close-reading exercises of Old Norse texts. By the end of the semester students should be able to read saga-style Old Norse prose texts in normalized orthography with the help of a dictionary. Assignments will include translations, grammatical exercises, quizzes, a midterm, and a final exam. Regular and active participation is required.</p>
<p>More details about this language <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/languages/old-norse/">here</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong> Zöega’s <em>Old Icelandic Dictionary </em>(any edition) and additional texts to be announced by the instructor.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> none</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1927 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1536" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 101B: Introduction to Old Norse II</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			TuTh 9:30-11 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2017</a>, 33 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/kate-heslop/">Kate Heslop</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong><em>L&amp;S Breadth: Arts &amp; Literature</em></strong></p>
<p><strong> </strong>In this, the second part of the Old Norse language course, we practice and extend the language skills learned in Old Norse 101A. Grammar topics from 101A will be repeated and deepened as needed. Students will both prepare translations out of class and work cooperatively on translating Old Norse texts during class time.</p>
<p>We will read a broad range of texts, intended to give a taste of the genres and styles of Old Norse prose and poetry, supplemented by secondary literature illuminating the historical context in which the primary texts were written, transmitted and read. Students will also learn how to work critically with modern editions and reference tools.</p>
<p>By the end of the course, students will have a solid basis for literary and philological work in the Old Norse field. They should be able to read Old Norse prose fluently and decode Old Norse poetry. They should also be capable of analyzing and situating Old Norse literary works in their literary, cultural and historical contexts.</p>
<p>Course Materials:<br />
Michael Barnes, <em>A New Introduction to Old Norse. Part I: Grammar</em>. London: Viking Society for Northern Research, 2008. ISBN 978-0-903521-74-1.</p>
<p>Anthony Faulkes, <em>A New Introduction to Old Norse. Part II: Reader</em>. London: Viking Society for Northern Research, 2011. ISBN 978-0-903521-83-3.</p>
<p>Anthony Faulkes, <em>A New Introduction to Old Norse. Part III: Glossary and Index of Names</em>. London: Viking Society for Northern Research, 2011. ISBN 978-0-903521-70-3.</p>
<p><em>The above three items can be downloaded for free from <a href="http://vsnrweb-publications.org.uk/">http://vsnrweb-publications.org.uk/</a></em></p>
<p>Rory McTurk, ed. <em>A Companion to Old Norse-Icelandic Literature and Culture</em>. Malden, MA: Blackwell, 2007. ISBN 978-1-4051-6367-5.</p>
<p>Geir T. Zoëga. <em>A Concise Dictionary of Old Icelandic.</em> Medieval Academy Reprints for Teaching. Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 2004 [or any other edition]. ISBN 978-0486434315.</p>
<p><u>Calculation of final grade</u><br />
Class participation: 40%<br />
Midterm: 10%<br />
Presentation: 10%<br />
Final exam: 40%</p>
<p>The course is assessed via a midterm, presentation and final exam. To receive full marks for participation, students will need to complete quizzes, regularly submit translations prepared out of class, and participate in-class translation exercises.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1536 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>

		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Året har 16 måneder: november<br />
december, januar, februar, marts, april<br />
maj, juni, juli, august, september<br />
oktober, november, november, november, november.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					The year has 16 months: November<br />
December, January, February, March, April<br />
May, June, July, August, September<br />
October, November, November, November, November. (Danish)				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Henrik Nordbrandt</span>
				
			</a>

<article id="post-1925" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 75: Literature and Culture of the Nordic World</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			TuTh 3:30-5 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 102 Wheeler. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/monica-hidalgo/">Monica Hidalgo</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>L&amp;S Breadth: </strong>Historical Studies OR Social and Behavioral Sciences</p>
<p>What are Nordic values? The countries of the northern Europe (Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden) have been caricatured in recent American political discourse as either utopian or dystopian alternatives to American culture (in that we do/don’t want to be “like Sweden” or “like Denmark”). But what are the complex cultural and historical realities that have made the contemporary Nordic region what it is today? Proceeding from three main areas of investigation (sustainable relationships to nature; values of social solidarity; and a progressive view of gender equality), the course traces the ways in which literature, drama, film, folklore, and other forms of humanistic expression have both revealed the pressure points implicit in Nordic values and in some cases contributed to their formation. Beginning its historical arc around 1650, this course traces the historical development of contemporary Nordic discussions in four main phases. We begin with the Nordic Enlightenment, which saw the decline of Danish and Swedish state power and colonization but also was an age of scientific advancement, social satire, and the growth of vernacular cultures. Next we study the nineteenth-century, where the familiar features of Scandinavian culture begin to take shape: the emergence of folk culture, the existential individual, and the new woman. These currents move forward into the early twentieth century formation of the Nordic welfare state and its design of modern political and urban environments. Finally the course will focus on the contemporary multicultural life of the North as seen through its crime fiction, popular culture, film, and television.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong>  none.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1925 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->
