<article id="post-1936" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 300A: Methods of Teaching Scandinavian Languages</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			Day/Time TBA <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 6410 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/karen-moller/">Karen Møller</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><em>Required of Scandinavian Department GSIs teaching languages.</em></p>
<p><em>Language GSIs also enroll in Scandinavian 300B, Section 1, Teaching Practicum:  Languages.</em></p>
<p><strong>Objectives: </strong></p>
<p>To gain:  A theoretical understanding of issues in foreign language learning and ability to critically evaluate methods and material.</p>
<p>An understanding of linguistic, psychological and cultural processes in foreign language learning.</p>
<p>A development of a repertoire of techniques to meet various teaching situations.</p>
<p>An ability to construct valid, reliable and practical evaluation measures.</p>
<p><strong>Participation: </strong> You will be asked to present a specific method to the class in a microteaching session, analyze the methodology in the teaching materials that you are using (2 pages), observe and report on another foreign language class (peer observation) (2 pages) and define and carry out a small research project in your class (5 pages).</p>
<p><strong>Required Readings:</strong>  Reader</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong>  GSI status in the Department of Scandinavian and also open to GSIs in other foreign language departments.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1936 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1709" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN R5B, Section 1: Place in Scandinavian Literature</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			TuTh 8-9:30 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2017</a>, 106 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/jenna-coughlin/">Jenna Coughlin</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: R</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>All Reading &amp; Composition courses must be taken for a letter grade in order to fulfill this requirement for the Bachelor’s Degree. This course satisfies the second half or the &#8220;B&#8221; portion of the Reading and Composition requirement. </strong></p>
<p>Place often becomes invisible in daily life. Not until we encounter a landscape or location that is somehow exceptional—a dramatic mountaintop, a sacred temple, an overwhelming city skyline—do we bring our attention to our surroundings. Whether depicting a remote, inhospitable seascape or the streets of a recently urbanized capital city, Scandinavian authors have used place as setting, symbol, and even character across a variety of genres. In this course, we will be reading texts by several major Scandinavian authors, while paying particular attention to place—the understandings of place apparent in them, the formal techniques used to depict place, and the changes that the Scandinavian relationship to place undergoes over time. We will also read several theorists of place and discuss their applicability to the Scandinavian context.</p>
<p>As a course designed to fulfill the objectives of Reading and Composition R5B, the main purpose of this course is to prepare students to complete an independent research project. As such, we will begin discussions in class which students will learn to pursue more deeply on their own. Along the way, we will practice critical reading, posing research questions, gathering sources, taking useful notes, and formulating original arguments that are supported with evidence, and, ultimately, presenting these results in an organized research essay, composed in a compelling and readable style.</p>
<p><strong>Texts: </strong></p>
<p><em>Synnøve Solbakken</em>, Bjørstjerne Bjørnsen (available through Google books)</p>
<p><em>The Lady from the Sea</em>, Henrik Ibsen (transl. Rolf Fjelde) ISBN: 0451528034</p>
<p><em>Hunger, </em>Knut Hamsun ISBN: 0141180641</p>
<p><em>A Summer’s Day, </em>Jon Fosse ISBN: 1840023848</p>
<p><em>The Ice Palace</em>, Tarjei Vesaas ISBN: 0720613299</p>
<p><em>Out of Africa</em>, Isak Dinesen (excerpts) ISBN: 0679724753</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong> Successful completion of the “A” portion of the Reading &amp; Composition requirement or its equivalent. <strong>Students may not enroll in nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</strong></p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1709 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1704" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN R5B, Section 6: Satire and the Enlightenment</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			TuTh 8-9:30 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2017</a>, 250 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/zachary-blinkinsop-2/">Zachary Blinkinsop</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>All Reading &amp; Composition courses must be taken for a letter grade in order to fulfill this requirement for the Bachelor’s Degree. This course satisfies the second half or the &#8220;B&#8221; portion of the Reading and Composition requirement. </strong></p>
<p>Satire flourished during the eighteenth century when heavy-hitting writers across Europe penned droll attacks on superstition, intolerance, and vice. In this course, we will explore how the satirical mode functioned as part of the Enlightenment project. Particular emphasis will placed on the literary history of Sweden and Denmark-Norway from 1720 to 1792. Guiding questions in the course include: when is satire subversive and when does it reinforce the status quo? How do Scandinavian satires differ from their contemporaries in Great Britain, France, and colonial America/the United States? Is there a taxonomy of satire and what formal elements are ubiquitous across satirical sub-genres? We will engage with scholarship on satire and the Enlightenment and students will write a term paper that incorporates scholarship, historical material, and one or more of the course texts. All readings are in English.</p>
<p><strong> Texts to Purchase:</strong><br />
Ludvig Holberg, <em>Niels Klim,</em> 978-0803273481</p>
<p>Voltaire, <em>Candide, </em>978-0140440041</p>
<p>Ogborn &amp; Buckroyd, <em>Satire, </em>978-0521787918</p>
<p>Course Reader with readings of various authors</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong> Successful completion of the “A” portion of the Reading &amp; Composition requirement or its equivalent. <strong>Students may not enroll in nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</strong></p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1704 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Havet . . . uden Krav, uden Forpligtelse, frit, rent og uforfalsket banker det store Hjerte -- det sidste sunde i den syge Verden.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					The sea . . . without demands, without commitment, free, pure and untainted beats its great heart -- the last healthy thing in a sick world. (Norwegian)				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Alexander Kielland</span>

<article id="post-1924" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN R5B, Section 4: Scandinavian Design</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			TuTh 8-9:30 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 205 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/ida-moen-johnson/">Ida Moen Johnson</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>This course satisfies the second half or the &#8220;B&#8221; portion of the Reading and Composition requirement. </strong></p>
<p><em> </em>Sleek furniture, minimalist clothing, and well-lit IKEA kitchens: these are the kinds of things that come to mind when one hears the phrase “Scandinavian design.” But we can think of Scandinavian design in broader terms as well, including the “design” of society, culture, and literature. This course explores texts that both celebrate and challenge notions of “good design” in a Scandinavian context. From houses and playgrounds, to landscapes and welfare states, we will consider questions such as: What is design? Is literature designed, or does it do the designing? What, if anything, is special about Scandinavian design?</p>
<p><strong>Texts: </strong></p>
<p><strong> </strong>Ibsen, Ghosts<br />
<strong>Publisher:</strong> Dover Publications; New edition edition (July 11, 1997)<br />
<strong>ISBN-10:</strong> 0486298523<br />
<strong>ISBN-13:</strong> 978-0486298528</p>
<p>Inger Christensen, alphabet<br />
<strong>Publisher:</strong> New Directions (May 17,2001) (1602)<br />
<strong>ASIN:</strong> B015X50TFM</p>
<p>Tarjei Vesaas, The Ice Palace<br />
<strong>Publisher:</strong> Peter Owen Publishers (May 1, 2009)<br />
<strong>ISBN-10:</strong> 0720613299<br />
<strong>ISBN-13:</strong> 978-0720613292</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong>  Successful completion of the “A” portion of the Reading &amp; Composition requirement or its equivalent.  <strong>Students may not enroll in nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</strong></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1924 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1532" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 160: Scandinavian Myth and Religion</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			MWF 3-4 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2017</a>, 166 Barrows. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/jackson-crawford-2/">Jackson Crawford</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>L&amp;S Breadth: Philosophy &amp; Values OR Arts &amp; Literature</strong></p>
<p>This course provides an overview and discussion of the major gods and goddesses, heroes and heroines, narratives and adventures which make up the lore collectively referred to as Scandinavian, or Norse, myth. This lore is chiefly preserved in two collections traditionally called the Poetic (or Elder) Edda and the Prose (or Younger) Edda, together with some mythical sagas. The course considers not only the myths themselves, but how we know what we know about the myths of medieval Scandinavia and nearby lands, and what we can learn about the culture of pre-Christian Scandinavia from the myths their Christian descendants left us. This course will also take a summary look at what we know about cognate traditions elsewhere in Northern Europe, especially England and Germany.</p>
<p>Learning Outcomes<br />
Students will finish the course with a comprehensive knowledge of pre-Christian Scandinavia’s mythology and religion, grounded in an understanding of the value of the primary sources as well as the directions of current research by scholars in the field.</p>
<p>Texts:</p>
<p>Snorri Sturluson, Edda. Trans. Anthony Faulkes (a vol. in the series Everyman Library). J.M. Dent, 1987 (or later) ISBN 978-0-460-87612-2.</p>
<p>The Poetic Edda. Trans. Jackson Crawford. Hackett Classics, 2015. ISBN 978-1-624-66356-7.</p>
<p>John Lindow, Norse Mythology: A Guide to the Gods, Heroes, Rituals, and Beliefs. Oxford Univ. Press, 2001. ISBN 978-0-19-515382-8.</p>
<p>Course Requirements<br />
Quizzes: 15%<br />
Composition: 15%<br />
Exams: 30%<br />
Final Exam: 35%</p>
<p>Prerequisites: None. Taught in English with readings in English</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1532 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1815" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN R5B, Section 1: Session A (May 22-June 30): The Nordic Child</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			TuWTh 1-3:30 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-summer/" rel="tag">Summer 2017</a>, 206 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/ida-moen-johnson/">Ida Moen Johnson</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
<p><strong>All Reading &amp; Composition courses must be taken for a letter grade in order to fulfill this requirement for the Bachelor’s Degree. This course satisfies the first half or the “B” portion of the Reading and Composition requirement.</strong></p>
<p>The child has a privileged status in Scandinavian societies, and is widely viewed as an autonomous and capable being. Scandinavian literature about children often brings out the tension between the child’s competence and vulnerability. For example, the Swedish character Pippi Longstocking lives by herself and can lift a horse above her head, but she breaks down in tears when she is told that she isn’t polite and is reminded that she doesn’t have a family. What do we imagine the child is capable of, and from what must he or she be protected? Do adults underestimate children? What, if anything, is the difference between children and adults? This course will examine these and other questions as we problematize the categories of ‘child’ and ‘adult,’ in literature and in life.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:  Successful completion of the “A” portion of the Reading and Composition requirement or its equivalent.  Students may not enroll nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</strong></p>
</div>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1815 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1817" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN R5B, Section 101: Session C (June 19-August 11): Into the Woods: The Forest in Scandinavian Literature</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			TuWTh 12-2 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-summer/" rel="tag">Summer 2017</a>, 254 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/jenna-coughlin/">Jenna Coughlin</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
<p><strong>All Reading &amp; Composition courses must be taken for a letter grade in order to fulfill this requirement for the Bachelor’s Degree. This course satisfies the first half or the “B” portion of the Reading and Composition requirement.</strong></p>
<p>This course will look at the tree in Scandinavian literature from its role in Old Norse creation mythology and cosmology to contemporary examinations of the materiality of the book, such as the “Future Library” project, in which books written by prominent authors will be printed on 1,000 trees harvested from Oslo’s Nordmarka in 2114. Along the way, we will examine how literature represents the ways in which humans relate to trees as metaphors, symbols, resources, and historical markers. Texts to be read include parts of the Poetic and Prose Eddas, relevant folktales, poetry by a variety of Scandinavian poets including Hans Børli, Tomas Tranströmer and Inger Christensen, Kerstin Ekman’s crime novel <i class="">Blackwater</i>, and Erlend Loe’s satire <i class="">Doppler</i>, as well as presentations of artists and writers whose work considers the relationship between forests, paper, and text. This course will provide students ample room to explore the topic from a variety of angles, and they should be able to find a wide variety of materials to support their research. In addition, the topic provides opportunities for exercises outside the classroom that take advantage of the variety of plant life on the Berkeley campus.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:  Successful completion of the “A” portion of the Reading and Composition requirement or its equivalent.  Students may not enroll nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</strong></p>
</div>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1817 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1818" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN R5B, Section 102: Session D (July 3-August 11): Migration and Mobility in the Viking Age: Global Perspectives</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			TuWTh 1-3:30 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-summer/" rel="tag">Summer 2017</a>, 250 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/sara-ann-knutson/">Sara Ann Knutson</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
<p><strong>All Reading &amp; Composition courses must be taken for a letter grade in order to fulfill this requirement for the Bachelor’s Degree. This course satisfies the first half or the “B” portion of the Reading and Composition requirement.</strong></p>
<p>Migration and travel have fundamentally shaped human history from its very beginnings. Whether forced or voluntary, human mobility across the globe has led to some definitive, transformative ruptures in history, from the Indo-Aryan migration from the Indus Valley, the expansion of the Mongols, invasions of the Roman Empire, the displacement of Africans in the Atlantic slave trade, and the recent forced relocation of thousands of Syrian refugees. The age of the Vikings, perhaps the most popularized moment of migration from Scandinavia, shares this long history of human mobility and cross-cultural exchanges.</p>
<p>This course will introduce students to the ways in which scholars ask questions, read and evaluate sources, and construct arguments. Acquiring training in textual analysis and argumentative writing, students will study the movement of people during the Viking Age, from trading and pilgrimage, to raiding and settlement. The course will explore a range of interdisciplinary approaches to history, including historical and literary sources, archaeological evidence, and scientific techniques, and will demonstrate how such evidence can be applied in academic papers. Through discussion of the motivations for travel and migration, our aim is to develop persuasive writing and to think critically about historical studies and their practical applications in our world today.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:  Successful completion of the “A” portion of the Reading and Composition requirement or its equivalent.  Students may not enroll nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</strong></p>
</div>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1818 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1819" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 160: Session D (July 3-August 11): Scandinavian Myth and Religion</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			TuWTh 1-3:30 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-summer/" rel="tag">Summer 2017</a>, 6415 Dwinelle Hall. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/jackson-crawford-2/">Jackson Crawford</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong><em>L&amp;S Breadth:  Philosophy &amp; Values OR Arts &amp; Literature</em></strong></p>
<p><em>Effective Thursday, July 13: This course now meets in 6415 Dwinelle Hall, Scandinavia Department seminar room.</em></p>
<p>This course provides an overview and discussion of the major gods and goddesses, heroes and heroines, narratives and adventures which make up the lore collectively referred to as Scandinavian, or Norse, myth. This lore is chiefly preserved in two collections traditionally called the Poetic (or Elder) Edda and the Prose (or Younger) Edda, together with some mythical sagas. The course considers not only the myths themselves, but how we know what we know about the myths of medieval Scandinavia and nearby lands, and what we can learn about the culture of pre-Christian Scandinavia from the myths their Christian descendants left us. This course will also take a summary look at what we know about cognate traditions elsewhere in Northern Europe, especially England and Germany. Students will finish the course with a comprehensive knowledge of pre-Christian Scandinavia’s mythology and religion, grounded in an understanding of the value of the primary sources as well as the directions of current research by scholars in the field.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong></p>
<p>Snorri Sturluson, <em>Edda</em>. Trans. Anthony Faulkes (a vol. in the series Everyman Library). J.M. Dent, 1987 (or later) ISBN 978-0-460-87612-2.</p>
<p><em>The Poetic Edda</em>. Trans. Jackson Crawford. Hackett Classics, 2015. ISBN 978-1-624-66356-7.</p>
<p>John Lindow, <em>Norse Mythology: A Guide to the Gods, Heroes, Rituals, and Beliefs</em>. Oxford Univ. Press, 2001. ISBN 978-0-19-515382-8.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong>  None.  Taught in English with readings in English.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1819 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<header id="site-header" class="home wideness" role="banner">
	<div class="upper-field">
		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Valr lá þar á sandi<br />
vitinn inum eineygja<br />
Friggjar faðmbyggvi;<br />
fǫgnuðum dáð slíkri.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					The slain lay there on the sand,<br />
dedicated to the one-eyed<br />
embrace-occupier of Frigg;<br />
we welcomed such doings. <br />
(Old Norse)				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Hrafnsmál, Stanza 12</span>
				
			</a>
			
									 
	
	
	</div>

<article id="post-1715" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 206: Studies in Philology and Linguistics: European Folklore Theory</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			W 3-6 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2017</a>, 6415 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/john-lindow/">John Lindow</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong><em>This course is cross-listed with Slavic 256 and Folklore C262B/Anthropology C262B.</em></strong></p>
<p>The European lands – especially the Nordic countries, Russia and the Balkan countries – are particularly rich in folklore materials, and scholars working on these materials have made major theoretical contributions to the general discipline of folklore. This course, intended both for students of general folklore and for students of Slavic or Scandinavian literatures, will survey these contributions both in terms of the folklore materials themselves and the theoretical advances made on the basis of these materials. Readings on theory will be in the Scandinavian languages, Russian, English and German. The folklore materials themselves are in the original languages (Danish, Norwegian, Swedish, Russian, Serbian, Bosnian); English translations are available of most of these materials. Students in Scandinavian and Slavic should be reading in the original to the extent possible; students of general folklore will do readings in English (and occasionally in German).</p>
<p><strong> Reading consists of selections from:</strong></p>
<p>Propp, Vladimir. <em>The Russian Folktale </em>(tr. Sibelan Forrester)</p>
<p>Propp, Vladimir. <em>Theory and History of Folklore</em> (ed. Anatoly Liberman)</p>
<p>Maranda, Pierre, ed. <em>Soviet Structural Folkloristics</em></p>
<p>Lord, Albert. <em>The Singer of Tales</em></p>
<p>Vidan, Aida. <em>Embroidered with Gold, Strung with Pearls, The Traditional Ballads of Bosnian Women</em></p>
<p>Aarne, Antti. <em>Verzeichnis der Märchentypen.</em></p>
<p>Holbek, Bengt. <em>Interpreting Fairy Tale</em>.</p>
<p>Sydov, C. W. von. <em>Selected Papers on Folklore.</em></p>
<p>Pentikainen, Juha. <em>The Nordic Dead-Child Tradition</em>.</p>
<p>Strömbäck, Dag. <em>Leading Folklorists of the North.</em></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Texts not available for purchase, as well as numerous others, will be made available either through library reserve or for downloading on bcourses</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites: </strong>Graduate standing; consent of instructors.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1715 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1714" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 301, Section 2: Teaching Methodology: Reading &amp; Composition</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			TuTh 8-9:30 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2017</a>, 6408 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/jonas-wellendorf/">Jonas Wellendorf</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 3</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>REQUIRED OF SCANDINAVIAN DEPARTMENT GSIs TEACHING READING &amp; COMPOSITION.</strong></p>
<p>This course is required of all Graduate Student Instructors teaching Reading &amp; Composition courses in the Scandinavian Department. Reading and Composition GSIs also enroll in Prof. Wellendorf’s Scandinavian 300B, Section 2 course for 1 unit.</p>
<p>Course to be repeated for credit each semester of employment as graduate student instructor. The purpose of this course is to introduce new GSIs to teaching Scandinavian R5A and R5B. It will focus on preparation of teaching materials, including syllabi, and discussion of questions of pedagogy (teaching literature and writing, lecturing, leading class discussions, designing writing assignments, grading and formulating responses to student papers, working with students individually and in small groups). The course will help you prepare for a career as a college teacher of literature and for the teaching component of job applications. Must be taken on a satisfactory/unsatisfactory basis.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong> Employment as graduate student instructor in the Department of Scandinavian.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1714 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1940" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 301, Section 2: Teaching Methodology: Reading &#038; Composition for Scandianvian GSIs</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			Day/Time TBA <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 6409 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/jonas-wellendorf/">Jonas Wellendorf</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 3</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>This course is required of all Graduate Student Instructors teaching Reading &amp; Composition courses in the Scandinavian Department.  Reading and Composition GSIs also enroll in Prof. Wellendorf’s Scandinavian 300B, Section 2 course for 1 unit.</p>
<p>Course to be repeated for credit each semester of employment as graduate student instructor.  The purpose of this course is to introduce new GSIs to teaching Scandinavian R5A and R5B. It will focus on preparation of teaching materials, including syllabi, and discussion of questions of pedagogy (teaching literature and writing, lecturing, leading class discussions, designing writing assignments, grading and formulating responses to student papers, working with students individually and in small groups). The course will help you prepare for a career as a college teacher of literature and for the teaching component of job applications.  Must be taken on a satisfactory/unsatisfactory basis.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong>  Employment as graduate student instructor in the Department of Scandinavian.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1940 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1713" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 301, Section 1: Teaching Methodology: Scandinavian Languages</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			TuTh 8-9:30 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2017</a>, 6410 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/karen-moller/">Karen Møller</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 3</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>REQUIRED OF SCANDINAVIAN DEPARTMENT GSIs TEACHING LANGUAGE COURSES</strong></p>
<p>This course is required of all Graduate Student Instructors teaching language courses in the Scandinavian Department. Language GSIs also enroll in Karen Moller’s Scandinavian 300B, section 1, language teaching practicum, for 1 unit. Must be taken on a satisfactory/unsatisfactory basis.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong> Employment as graduate student instructor in the Department of Scandinavian.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1713 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1939" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 301, Section 1: Teaching Methodology: Scandinavian Languages</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			Day/Time TBA <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 6410 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/karen-moller/">Karen Møller</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 3</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>This course is required of all Graduate Student Instructors teaching language courses in the Scandinavian Department.  Language GSIs also enroll in Karen Moller’s Scandinavian 300B, section 1, language teaching practicum, for 1 unit.  Must be taken on a satisfactory/unsatisfactory basis.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong>  Employment as graduate student instructor in the Department of Scandinavian.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1939 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1712" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 300B, Section 2: Teaching Practicum: Reading &amp; Composition for Scandinavian GSIs</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			MWF 8-9 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2017</a>, 6408 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/jonas-wellendorf/">Jonas Wellendorf</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 1</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>REQUIRED OF SCANDINAVIAN DEPARTMENT GSIs TEACHING READING &amp; COMPOSITION</strong></p>
<p>This course is required of all Graduate Student Instructors teaching Reading &amp; Composition courses in the Scandinavian Department. Reading and Composition GSIs also enroll in Prof. Wellendorf’s Scandinavian 301, Section 2 course for 3 units.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite</strong>: GSI status in the Department of Scandinavian.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1712 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1938" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 300B, Section 2: Teaching Practicum: Reading &#038; Composition for Scandinavian GSIs</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			Day/Time TBA <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 6409 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/jonas-wellendorf/">Jonas Wellendorf</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 1</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>This course is required of all Graduate Student Instructors teaching Reading &amp; Composition courses in the Scandinavian Department.  Reading and Composition GSIs also enroll in Prof. Wellendorf’s Scandinavian 301, Section 2 course for 3 units.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite</strong>:  GSI status in the Department of Scandinavian.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1938 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

<article id="post-1711" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 300B, Section 1: Teaching Practicum: Scandinavian Languages</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			MWF 8-9 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2017</a>, 6410 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/karen-moller/">Karen Møller</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 1</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>REQUIRED OF SCANDINAVIAN DEPARTMENT GSIs TEACHING LANGUAGE COURSES</strong></p>
<p>This course is required of all Graduate Student Instructors teaching Norwegian and Swedish courses in the Scandinavian Department. Language GSIs also enroll in Scandinavian 300A, Methods of Teaching Scandinavian Languages.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong> GSI status in the Department of Scandinavian.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1711 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1937" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 300B, Section 1: Teaching Practicum: Scandinavian Languages</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			Day/Time TBA <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 6410 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/karen-moller/">Karen Møller</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 1</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><em>Required of Scandinavian Department GSIs teaching language courses.</em></p>
<p>This course is required of all graduate student instructors teaching Norwegian and Swedish courses in the Scandinavian Department. Language GSIs also enroll in Scandinavian 300A (Methods of Teaching Scandinavian Languages).</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite: </strong>GSI status in the Department of Scandinavian.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1937 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1917" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN R5A, Section 1: The Fairytales of Hans Christian Andersen</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			TuTh 8-9:30 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 228 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/troy-smith/">Troy Wellington Smith</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>This course satisfies the first half or the &#8220;A&#8221; portion of the Reading and Composition requirement. </strong></p>
<p>Children all over the world have grown up with Hans Christian Andersen’s fairytales, such as “The Little Mermaid,” “The Ugly Duckling,” and “The Emperor’s New Clothes,” as they have been translated from Danish into over 125 languages. Although Andersen originally subtitled his fairytale collections “Told for Children,” he was equally interested in reaching an adult audience. The fairytales therefore address the burgeoning modernity of Andersen’s Denmark, and the issues that arose with it, many of which are still relevant today: e.g., the consequences of technology; the role of women and girls in society; the risks of conformist thinking; and the unique psychology of children. Unlike the Brothers Grimm, who collected folktales passed down through the oral tradition, Andersen based the vast majority of his fairytales on literary sources, or invented them with his own imagination; fairytales of this sort are known as <em>Kunstmärchen</em> (“art-fairytales”). In order to contrast Andersen with the folkloric tradition, this course will begin with readings in translation of the German folklore of the Grimms and the Norwegian folktales collected by Asbjørnsen and Moe. We will then read Andersen’s fairytales in translation and observe how the <em>Kunstmärchen</em> genre gave Andersen the freedom to respond to the challenges of a modernizing and evolving Europe. Along the way, we will supplement our reading of the fairytales with scholarly articles, and broaden our discussion by examining modern adaptations of Andersen’s work, such as Disney’s <em>Frozen</em>.</p>
<p><strong>Texts: </strong></p>
<p><em>Hans Christian Andersen: The Complete Fairy Tales and Stories </em></p>
<p>ISBN: 978-0385189514</p>
<p>Course reader</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong>  Successful completion of the UC Entry Level Writing Requirement or its equivalent.  <strong>Students may not enroll in nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</strong></p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1917 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Havet . . . uden Krav, uden Forpligtelse, frit, rent og uforfalsket banker det store Hjerte -- det sidste sunde i den syge Verden.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					The sea . . . without demands, without commitment, free, pure and untainted beats its great heart -- the last healthy thing in a sick world. (Norwegian)				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Alexander Kielland</span>

<article id="post-1922" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN R5B, Section 2: The Machiavellian Narrative</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			TuTh 8-9:30 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 105 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/monica-hidalgo/">Monica Hidalgo</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>This course satisfies the second half or the “B” portion of the Reading and Composition requirement. </strong></p>
<p>The purpose of this course is to familiarize students with the forms and mechanics of academic writing. As a guiding theme, we will read, analyze, and respond to short stories and novels that toy with our desire to understand characters’ true motivations—these are known as Machiavellian narratives, named after the Italian political theorist notorious for advocating trickery, subterfuge, and fear-mongering as effective methods of rule.</p>
<p>The power of Machiavellian narratives will be explored through Scandinavian texts, including Victoria Benedictsson’s “From the Darkness,” St. St. Blicher’s “Tardy Awakening,” Knut Hamsun’s <em>Hunger</em>, Hjalmar Söderberg’s <em>Doctor Glas</em>, and Pär Lagerkvist’s <em>The Dwarf.</em> While we may not be accustomed to thinking too much about a story’s narrator as a character, Machiavellian narratives raise the question of how much we can trust a story’s narrator. How do we know what the narrator tells us is true? Does the narrator have an interest in telling us certain things but not others about the characters in the novel? What does the narrator think of the reader listening to his or her tale? By raising these questions, students will become more adept at identifying manipulative narratorial moves, discerning and analyzing the power constellations governing fiction, and, most importantly, developing the analytical skills necessary to becoming successful academic writers.</p>
<p><strong>Texts: </strong></p>
<p><strong> </strong>Hamsun, Knut. <em>Hunger</em>. Trans. Robert Bly. Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 1998. ISBN-13: 978-0374525286</p>
<p><strong> </strong>Lagerkvist, Pär. <em>The Dwarf</em>. Trans. Alexandra Dick. Hill and Wang, 1958. ISBN-13: 978-0374521356</p>
<p>Söderberg, Hjalmar. <em>Doctor Glas. </em>Trans. Paul Bitten Austin. Anchor, 2002. ISBN-13: 978-0385722674</p>
<p>*Additional readings will be made available in a course reader or bCourses.</p>
<p><strong> Prerequisites:  </strong>Successful completion of the first half or “A” portion of the Reading and Composition requirement.  <strong>Students may not enroll nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</strong></p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1922 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Hvis jeg visste hva som var meningen med livet, trengte jeg ikke å skrive. Da kunne jeg bare sitte og vite.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					If I knew the meaning of life, I wouldn’t need to write—I could just sit around knowing it. (Norwegian)				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Erlend Loe</span>

<article id="post-1707" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN R5B, Section 3: The Machiavellian Narrative</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			MWF 8-9 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2017</a>, 130 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/monica-hidalgo/">Monica Hidalgo</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>All Reading &amp; Composition courses must be taken for a letter grade in order to fulfill this requirement for the Bachelor’s Degree. This course satisfies the second half or the “B” portion of the Reading and Composition requirement. </strong></p>
<p>The purpose of this course is to familiarize students with the forms and mechanics of academic writing. As a guiding theme, we will read, analyze, and respond to short stories and novels that toy with our desire to understand characters’ true motivations—these are known as Machiavellian narratives, named after the Italian political theorist notorious for advocating trickery, subterfuge, and fear-mongering as effective methods of rule.</p>
<p>The power of Machiavellian narratives will be explored through Scandinavian texts, including Victoria Benedictsson’s “From the Darkness,” St. St. Blicher’s “Tardy Awakening,” Knut Hamsun’s <em>Hunger</em>, Hjalmar Söderberg’s <em>Doctor Glas</em>, and Pär Lagerkvist’s <em>The Dwarf.</em> While we may not be accustomed to thinking too much about a story’s narrator as a character, Machiavellian narratives raise the question of how much we can trust a story’s narrator. How do we know what the narrator tells us is true? Does the narrator have an interest in telling us certain things but not others about the characters in the novel? What does the narrator think of the reader listening to his or her tale? By raising these questions, students will become more adept at identifying manipulative narratorial moves, discerning and analyzing the power constellations governing fiction, and, most importantly, developing the analytical skills necessary to becoming successful academic writers.</p>
<p><strong>Texts: </strong></p>
<p>Hamsun, Knut. <em>Hunger</em>. Trans. Robert Bly. Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 1998. ISBN-13: 978-0374525286</p>
<p>Lagerkvist, Pär. <em>The Dwarf</em>. Trans. Alexandra Dick. Hill and Wang, 1958. ISBN-13: 978-0374521356</p>
<p>Söderberg, Hjalmar. <em>Doctor Glas. </em>Trans. Paul Bitten Austin. Anchor, 2002. ISBN-13: 978-0385722674</p>
<p>*Additional readings will be made available in a course reader or bCourses.</p>
<p><strong> Prerequisites: </strong>Successful completion of the first half or “A” portion of the Reading and Composition requirement. <strong>Students may not enroll nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</strong></p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1707 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->

The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1932" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 150: Nature in Scandinavian Literature and Culture</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			MWF 1-2 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 6307 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/jenna-coughlin/">Jenna Coughlin</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>L&amp;S Breadth:  </strong>Arts &amp; Literature</p>
<p>The Scandinavian countries are known for their distinctive nature, from the geysers and glaciers of Iceland to the fjords of Norway to the vast forests of Sweden and Finland. While natural features may seem to provide static background for culture, understandings of nature have in fact shifted over time in accordance with human concerns. Literature plays a significant role in carrying out these shifts. In recent years, literature has also stopped to ask how we arrived at our present moment, when human impact on the planet seems to be remaking the notions of nature on which human life and thought are based. In this case, literature performs a critique of the past and speculates about possible futures.</p>
<p>This course examines the representation of nature and the environment in the Scandinavian context from the creation narratives of Norse myth through the project of 19<sup>th</sup> century nation-building and up to present concerns about climate change and environmental destruction. Students will encounter central works that have produced and contested notions of nature. Alongside these, they will read significant theoretical texts from the field of ecocriticism. This will provide an entryway into the environmental humanities, while also providing an opportunity to explore what makes Scandinavian literature and culture unique.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:  </strong>to be announced.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong>  None.  The course and readings are in English.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1932 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1705" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN R5B, Section 2: The Uncanny Double</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			TuTh 8-9:30 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2017</a>, 206 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/rosie-taylor/">Rosie Taylor</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>All Reading &amp; Composition courses must be taken for a letter grade in order to fulfill this requirement for the Bachelor’s Degree. This course satisfies the second half or the &#8220;B&#8221; portion of the Reading and Composition requirement. </strong></p>
<p>While the motif of the double is not exclusive to Scandinavia, its presence has been felt in Nordic Gothic literature since the early 19<sup>th</sup> century, inspired by literary translations from Britain and continental Europe. This course will trace the evolution of the Gothic and uncanny double from the late 19<sup>th</sup> century to today, looking at both time and culture as factors in its development. We will begin by getting a feel for the classic double in Western texts by way of landmark works such as Robert Louis Stevenson’s <em>The Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde</em>. The course will then move to Nordic literature and its own interpretation of the Gothic to explore the changes undergone by the double in the Scandinavian environment through works by Henrik Ibsen, Selma Lagerlöf, Karen Blixen and more. At its core, this course will explore how the motif of the double can be employed to better understand social anxieties and issues in the Nordic countries and beyond up to the modern day.</p>
<p>The aim of this course is to help students further their skills in reading, analysis and composition, and to feel more confident participating in existing academic debates. The semester will culminate in a research project designed for students to learn how to find, analyze and engage with secondary sources at the university level.</p>
<p><strong>Texts: </strong></p>
<p>Thomas Tryon, <em>The Other</em> (NYRB Classics, ISBN: 978-1590175835)</p>
<p>Course Reader</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong> Successful completion of the “A” portion of the Reading &amp; Composition requirement or its equivalent. <strong>Students may not enroll in nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</strong></p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1705 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1706" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 106: The Works of Hans Christian Andersen</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			MWF 1-2 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2017</a>, 219 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/monica-hidalgo/">Monica Hidalgo</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>In this course, we will read works by the famous Danish writer Hans Christian Andersen (1805-75), focusing primarily on his exciting experiments with the genre of the literary fairytale. He is best known for fairytales such as “The Little Mermaid,” “The Ugly Duckling,” and “The Emperor’s New Clothes.” Although fairytales are often seen as children’s literature, Andersen’s fairytales contain themes appropriate for adults as well. Accordingly, his fairytales can be read in multifaceted ways that help uncover key psychological, social, and sexual themes at play.</p>
<p>To better understand Andersen in his historical and cultural context, we will also read excerpts from some of his other works, including poems, short stories, novels, plays, travel descriptions, autobiographies, and diaries. Additionally, we will view film adaptations and look at illustrated versions of his fairytales while discussing his works in the context of both Scandinavian perceptions of childhood and the evolving market for children’s literature. Seeing Andersen from such a holistic perspective reveals the underlying tensions at work in his writing and casts him as an innovative and daring writer.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong></p>
<p>Hans Christian Andersen’s <em>Complete Fairy Tales and Stories</em>. ISBN-13: 978-0385189514</p>
<p>All other required materials will be available in the form of a reader.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> None. All readings in English.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1706 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1934" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 250: Seminar in Scandinavian Literature: Things in Literature</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			F 1-4 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 6415 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/karin-sanders/">Karin Sanders</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>What happens when <em>things</em> play a part in literature? Bottles, walking sticks, umbrellas, amulets, jewelry, furniture, and so on, often carry significance far beyond the apparent value and function they are assigned. Things can speak volumes about genre, plot, personification, tropes and so forth. They can articulate nostalgia for the authentic real or they can become uncanny if we are in doubt as to their status or ontology. They can be made to speak manifestly like anthropomorphic beings or implicitly and metaphorically. When things ‘come alive’ in literature they can reflect on the nature of writing (pen, ink, book) or they can serve as mnemonics within a fictional text. Things can form poetic lists, suggest social or psychological value when given as gifts, point to a culture of commodification, or serve as exotic souvenirs. In short, things take on a host of inflections, not least in shaping an ecology of sorts in the relationship between humans and things. The interest in materiality and material culture in literary studies in recent years has produced a subfield, aptly named “Thing Theory” (Bill Brown). This seminar will examine thing theory by way of analytical examples culled from a variety of genres from Icelandic sagas to Danish fairytales to Norwegian novels to Swedish poems (the list of primary texts will be selected in concert with seminar participants’ interests), often in conversation with selected excerpts from major international writers like Dickens, Kleist, Rilke, Kafka, and Borges. Critical thinkers will include Karl Marx, Martin Heidegger, Walter Benjamin and Roland Barthes; and we will consult recent works on thing theory such as Bill Brown (“Thing Theory”, <em>A Sense of Things</em>), W.J.T. Mitchell (“Romanticism and the Life of Things”), Elaine Freedgoodd (<em>The Ideas in Things.</em>), Peter Schwenger (<em>The Tears of Things</em>), Miguel Tamen (<em>Friends of Interpretable Objects</em>), Barbara Johnson (<em>Persons and Things</em>), Jonathan Lamb (<em>The Things Things Say</em>), Mark Blackwell (<em>The Secret Life of Things</em>), Susan Stewart (<em>On Longing)</em>, Jane Bennett (<em>Vibrant Matter</em>).</p>
<p>Themes include: Gift (exchange, value), Memory (nostalgia, trauma), Reification (objectification, anthropomorphism, personification); Counterfeit (fake value, ethics), Ecology (nature, man).</p>
<p><strong> Prerequisites:  </strong>Graduate standing; consent of instructor<strong>.</strong></p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1934 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Þat eru bókrúnar, <br />
þat eru bjargrúnar,<br />
ok allar ǫlrúnar,<br />
ok mætar meginrúnar.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					That is book-runes, <br />
that is birth-runes, <br />
and all ale-runes, <br />
and the famed power-runes.<br />
(Old Norse)				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Sigrdrífumál, stanza 19</span>
				
			</a>
			
									 
	
	
	</div>

<article id="post-1923" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN R5B, Section 3: Viking Age Scandinavia and the East</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			MWF 8-9 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 187 Dwinelle. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/rosie-taylor/">Rosie Taylor</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>This course satisfies the second half or the &#8220;B&#8221; portion of the Reading and Composition requirement. </strong></p>
<p><em> </em>The Vikings are remembered today for their raids—but they also made a name for themselves through their voyages to the edges of the medieval world. Touching down on four continents, they pushed the borders of the map in their endeavors as raiders, merchants, mercenaries and explorers. This course will follow the Norsemen on some of these journeys, beginning with local voyages in and around Scandinavia and expanding to their most far-flung destinations in the East. From the Russian steppes to the Caspian Sea, through the Byzantine Empire and beyond, we will look to literary as well as archaeological evidence to explore the impact of the Norsemen on their foreign surroundings, and vice versa. Why did they travel? What did they learn in these foreign societies? And what did they bring home with them?</p>
<p>The aim of this course is to help students further their skills in reading, analysis and composition, and to feel more confident participating in existing academic debates. The semester will culminate in a research project designed for students to learn how to find, analyze and engage with secondary sources at the university level.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong></p>
<p>Course reader</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong>  Successful completion of the “A” portion of the Reading &amp; Composition requirement or its equivalent.  <strong>Students may not enroll in nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</strong></p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1923 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Ef allir hlutir í heiminum, kykvir ok dauðir, gráta hann, þá skal hann fara til Ása aptr.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					If all things in the world, living as well as dead, cry for him, he shall return to the Æsir. (Old Norse) 				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Gylfaginning, chap. 49</span>
				
			</a>

<article id="post-1930" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SCANDINAVIAN 123: Viking and Medieval Scandinavia</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								
			MWF 10-11 <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/courses-category/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a>, 102 Wheeler. 
 			
 							
														<b>Instructor: 
    								        
            					<a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/jonas-wellendorf/">Jonas Wellendorf</a>

																 
												
							</p>
							
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>L&amp;S Breadth: </strong>Historical Studies</p>
<p>Viking and Medieval Scandinavia will explore developments and trends in the areas of social structure, trade and economy, religion, political organization, culture, literature, and technology during the Viking and Medieval periods (c. 700-1500). The course will cover the Scandinavian homelands (Denmark, Sweden, Norway) as well as the regions settled by Scandinavians during the Viking Age. Developments in Scandinavia will be contextualized against broader trends in Europe and western Asia.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong> John Haywood, <em>The Penguin Historical Atlas of the Vikings </em>(1995), Stefan Brink and Neil Price, eds. (2008) <em>The Viking World</em>; Else Roesdahl (1999) <em>The Vikings</em> and a selection of primary sources in tran</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> None.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1930 -->
</div>

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->
