<article id="post-447" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Full List of Courses Offered</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The courses listed here are those taught with some frequency in the department. There are additional approved catalog courses not listed here, but these are the Scandinavian classes that students can expect to encounter within a 2-4 year cycle (courses followed by asterisks are taught on an annual basis):</p>
<p><strong>Language Course Sequences</strong></p>
<p>Danish 1A and 1B: Beginning and Intermediate Danish*<br />
Scandinavian 100A and 100B: Scandinavian Languages and Linguistics (Danish section)*</p>
<p>Finnish 1A and 1B: Beginning Finnish*<br />
Finnish 102A and 102B: Intermediate and Advanced Finnish*</p>
<p>Icelandic 1A and 1B: Beginning and Intermediate Icelandic</p>
<p>Norwegian 1A and 1B: Beginning and Intermediate Norwegian*<br />
Scandinavian 100A and 100B: Scandinavian Languages and Linguistics (Norwegian section)*</p>
<p>Swedish 1A and 1B: Beginning and Intermediate Swedish*<br />
Scandinavian 100A and 100B: Scandinavian Languages and Linguistics (Swedish section)*</p>
<p>Scandinavian 101A and 101B: Introduction to Old Norse I-II</p>
<p><strong>Reading and Composition Courses</strong></p>
<p>Scandinavian R5A*<br />
Scandinavian R5B*</p>
<p><strong>Lower-Division Survey Courses</strong></p>
<p>Scandinavian 60: Heroic Legends of the North*<br />
Scandinavian 75: Literature and Culture of the Nordic World*</p>
<p><strong>Upper-Division Elective Courses taught in English</strong></p>
<p>Scandinavian 106: The Works of Hans Christian Andersen<br />
Scandinavian C107: The Plays of Ibsen<br />
Scandinavian C108: The Works of Strindberg<br />
Scandinavian 115: Studies in Drama and Film (variable topics)<br />
Scandinavian 116: Studied in Prose (variable topics)<br />
Scandinavian 120: The Novel in Scandinavia (variable topics)<br />
Scandinavian 123: Viking and Medieval Scandinavia<br />
Scandinavian 125: Old Norse Literature<br />
Scandinavian 132: Introduction to Finnish Culture and History<br />
Scandinavian 149: Major Studies<br />
Scandinavian C160: Scandinavian Myth and Religion</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-447 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/courses.jpg" class="tooltip" title="Potholders made of bright woolen balls are created using a traditional felting technique. The signature bold, colorful look was first made famous by Marimekko in the 1950s. Marimekko&rsquo;s vibrant yet simple designs in clothing and home furnishings flourished in 1960s international pop culture and still influence Finnish design today." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Ef allir hlutir í heiminum, kykvir ok dauðir, gráta hann, þá skal hann fara til Ása aptr.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					If all things in the world, living as well as dead, cry for him, he shall return to the Æsir. (Old Norse) 				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Gylfaginning, chap. 49</span>
				
			</a>

<article id="post-722" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">ISSA Reimbursement Forms</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>Faculty or students in the Department of Scandinavian in need of reimbursements for allowable expenses should complete the relevant form, print and sign a paper copy, and attach all relevant receipts. Return completed forms and documents to Elizabeth LaVarge-Baptista in 6311 Dwinelle or to her mailbox in 6303 Dwinelle.</p>
<p><em>Please do not save copies of these forms for future use &#8212; they are frequently updated, and you will find the latest versions here.</em></p>
<p><a href="https://csstravelform.berkeley.edu/">Domestic Travel</a></p>
<p><em>Note: This form needs to be completed online in order to utilize the drop down menus.</em></p>
<p><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Intl-Travel-Form-7-17-2015.pdf">International Travel</a></p>
<p><em>Note: For this form to print with proper formatting, you should download to Adobe first, then print.</em></p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://aoprals.state.gov/web920/per_diem.asp">Foreign Per Diem Rates</a>, USD, based on the month in which the traveler arrived in the country.</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Entertainment-Reimbursement-Form-6-16-2016.pdf">Entertainment</a></p>
<p><em>Note: For this form to print with proper formatting, you should download to Adobe first, then print.</em></p>
<p><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/General-Reimbursement-Request-Form.pdf">General Reimbursements</a></p>
<p><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Certificate-of-Lost-or-Missing-Receipt.pdf">Certificate of Lost or Missing Receipt</a> Travel and Entertainment: for expenses $75+ for which there is no itemized receipt or no receipt at all. General: required if missing an itemized receipt or proof of payment.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>For examples, see below:</p>
<p><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/domestic-travel_Page_1.jpg" rel="lightbox[722]">Domestic Travel Reimbursement INSTRUCTIONS</a> <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/domestic-travel_Page_2.jpg" rel="lightbox[722]">(pg 2)</a></p>
<p><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/International-Form.jpg" rel="lightbox[722]">International Travel Reimbursement INSTRUCTIONS</a></p>
<p><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Entertainment-Reimbursement-TO-ANNOTATE.jpg" rel="lightbox[722]">Entertainment Reimbursement INSTRUCTIONS</a></p>
<p><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/General-Reimbursement.jpg" rel="lightbox[722]">General Reimbursement INSTRUCTIONS</a></p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-722 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/resources.jpg" class="tooltip" title="This <em>bildsten</em> (picture stone) from Gotland in Sweden may predate the Viking Age with its estimated date of 400-600 A.D. It is from the Sanda Church and can now be found at Fornsalen in Visby&rsquo;s Gotlands Museum." alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-457" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">M.A./Ph.D. Program</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The graduate program in Scandinavian is designed to train future scholars, teachers, translators, and other research professionals in the fields of Scandinavian language, literature, and cultural history. The department&#8217;s strengths lie in modern literatures (Danish, Norwegian, and Swedish), Old Norse and medieval studies, film studies and visual culture, and in broad interdisciplinary fields of the intellectual and cultural history of the North. Graduate students in this program are expected to work comparatively across the Nordic region using one specific language and literature field as a foundation. The program is especially designed to accommodate interdisciplinary work in all fields and periods.</p>
<p>The Department of Scandinavian does not admit students who have the M.A. as a final career goal; admission is granted to the combined M.A./Ph.D. program. Students with M.A. degrees in Scandinavian from other comparable institutions, however, will apply directly to the Ph.D. program at UCB and petition to proceed without repeating the M.A.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>For more information on professional development, research, and teaching, visit the Graduate Division&#8217;s <a href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/professional-development/guide/">Professional Development Guide and calendar</a>.</p>
<p><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/2015-01-15-10.39.50.jpg" rel="lightbox[457]" title="2015-01-15 10.39.50"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1064" src="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/2015-01-15-10.39.50-300x169.jpg" alt="2015-01-15 10.39.50" width="300" height="169" /></a></p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-457 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/programs.jpg" class="tooltip" title="The &ldquo;ant chair&rdquo; gets its name from the thorax shape of the back and seat, and was designed in 1952 by the influential Danish architect and designer Arne Jacobsen (1902-71) to be modular, light, and easily stackable. " alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-461" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Academic Requirements</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<h2 class="anchored-header">M.A. Requirements</h2>
<p>The purpose of the M.A. phase of Berkeley&#8217;s Scandinavian graduate program is to provide students with a fundamental knowledge of Scandinavian literary culture over the course of its history, including a substantial introduction to the interdisciplinary field of Scandinavian.</p>
<p><em>Coursework</em><br />
The minimum enrollment requirement for full-time graduate students at Berkeley is 12 units per semester—which is usually three regular (4-unit, 200 series) graduate seminars. In some cases, students may undertake undergraduate coursework in areas of special need or interest, after consultation with the Graduate Adviser.</p>
<p>The M.A. degree requires a minimum of 24 semester units (two full-time semesters) of combined upper-division and graduate courses taken for a letter grade. The department expects the completion of one or two graded research seminar papers per semester, including the department&#8217;s course in literary theory, though exceptions are made during exam semesters.</p>
<p>For the Scandinavian M.A., the minimum SIX letter-graded department seminars (24 units)<br />
must include Scandinavian 210, the seminar in literary theory (taught every other year); may include two seminars in Old Norse (required for the Ph.D. and often taken in the first two years); and may include two seminars in modern Scandinavian literature (required for the Ph.D. and often taken in the first two years). The specific courses required for each student will be determined by the Graduate Adviser in consultation with the departmental faculty at the time of enrollment and are based on an evaluation of the student&#8217;s prior training in the field of Scandinavian.</p>
<p><em>The Exam</em><br />
Students begin preparing a reading list file during the first semester of enrollment in the program, using texts covered in seminars whenever appropriate. The file comprises two sub-lists, covering major and minor fields. Each student’s final major-field list provides broad coverage of periods, genres and authorship within a single-language literary culture. The department has designed template reading lists for M.A. major fields in Old Norse, Danish, Norwegian and Swedish which are included in the program handbook. The minor list is comparative or interdisciplinary, and designed around a special topic of the student’s choice in consultation with the relevant supervising faculty member.</p>
<p>The M.A. exam consists of three written 8-hour take-home exams given within a one-week period; two questions cover the major field and one the minor field. An oral exam of approximately 1 ½ to 2 hours with the examining committee (comprised of three members of the department faculty) follows. Exams are judged on the ability to show comprehensive historical knowledge of literary periods, genres, central authorships as well as ability to connect and conceptualize ideas across historical periods and genre boundaries.</p>
<p>The full description of the M.A. program degree requirements, including explicit policies and procedures are detailed in the Graduate Program Handbook.</p>
<h2 class="anchored-header">Ph.D. Requirements</h2>
<p>To enroll in the Ph.D. program in Scandinavian, a Master’s degree in Scandinavian or equivalent preparation is prerequisite. The Ph.D. program expects students to broaden and sharpen previous training, presumes a broad knowledge of Scandinavian literature and culture from the Viking Age through the 20th centuries, and inculcates advanced training in the interdisciplinary field of Scandinavian. The program involves three stages:</p>
<ul>
<li>Teaching and Ph.D. coursework</li>
<li>Advancement to Candidacy</li>
<li>Dissertation Phase.</li>
</ul>
<p>The degree is awarded in recognition of a candidate&#8217;s comprehensive mastery of a broad field of learning, and for distinguished accomplishment in that field through an original contribution of significant knowledge—the dissertation.</p>
<p><em>Coursework</em><br />
The department’s required coursework normally takes 1.5 to 2 years of full-time (12 units per semester) enrollment. Specific departmental requirements for the Ph.D. include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Two seminars in Old Norse</li>
<li>Two seminars in modern Scandinavian Literature</li>
<li>Two semesters teaching a Scandinavian language (teaching a Reading and Composition course is also desirable, but not required)</li>
<li>Demonstrated competent reading knowledge of two foreign languages beyond the major Scandinavian language (one of which may be another Scandinavian language)</li>
<li>Two field papers submitted for faculty approval</li>
</ul>
<p>When beginning the Ph.D. program, the student will meet with the Graduate Adviser to discuss appropriate coursework and requirements based on previous academic training. All Ph.D. students are required to continue coursework beyond the M.A., but the exact number of units depends upon the nature of the student’s experience. Students develop expertise in three equally weighted fields and prepare for the Qualifying Examination in their areas of specialization. Students who have completed the M.A. in Scandinavian at Berkeley, and have been granted permission to proceed, are required to finish the following requirements if they have not already done so:</p>
<ul>
<li>201A and 201B, the introductory Old Norse seminars</li>
<li>Two elective seminars in modern Scandinavian literature</li>
</ul>
<p>Additional Ph.D. coursework may include up to two seminars offered in another department. Exceptions may be approved in some cases (e.g. in conjunction with a Designated Emphasis) by the Graduate Adviser. The balance of coursework includes elective courses taken inside the Department chosen in consultation with the Graduate Adviser and major research professor. Students are particularly urged to take courses in theory and method both inside and outside the department.</p>
<p>Students who come with an M.A. in Scandinavian from another program usually complete additional semesters of supplementary coursework in order to broaden their training in Scandinavian literary cultures and correlate with our Master program. The exact courses and number of units are determined by the Graduate Adviser in consultation with other department faculty at the time of enrollment, and depends on previous preparation in the field of Scandinavian. (Examples include the Scandinavian seminar in literary theory, Graduate Division language requirements, etc.)</p>
<p><em>Field papers</em><br />
Two faculty-approved field papers are required by the end of the third week of the semester in which the written Ph.D. qualifying exam takes place. This is typically a research paper revised beyond the level of seminar work which represents the student’s best effort and reflects the standards of the discipline.</p>
<p><em>The Qualifying Examination</em><br />
The purpose of the Qualifying Exam is to test the student’s mastery over broad areas of knowledge. The exam offers the student an opportunity to synthesize factual information and training in techniques absorbed through instruction and individual research, and to demonstrate readiness to enter the dissertation phase of graduate study by showing evidence of independent critical thought and writing.</p>
<p>During the coursework phase, students compile three reading lists for the Qualifying Exam. The lists are designed using these categories:</p>
<ul>
<li>A diachronic examination of a single language’s literary culture</li>
<li>A synchronic comparison of literature spanning at least two language traditions (for modernists), or Old Norse and one other medieval literary tradition (for medievalists)</li>
<li>A list designed around a thematic, theoretical, or special-interest field, preferably of relevance to the eventual dissertation topic.</li>
</ul>
<p>The specific content of the three fields is defined in conjunction with the examining committee and the Graduate Adviser. Lists may repeat items from the major and minor UCB Scandinavian M.A. exam lists, but an item may not be listed on more than one Ph.D. list. The examination is partly based on the reading lists (which represent a minimum of preparation), but also on expected familiarity with other important or representative works.</p>
<p>The four-member examining committee is appointed in consultation with the student and Graduate Adviser, and must include a UCB Senate faculty member from outside the department (this can also be the representative for an official Designated Emphasis). Final approval of the committee is made by the Graduate Division when the student requests permission to take the exam.</p>
<p>Written take-home exams take place over three days—by email—in which the student has 12 hours to prepare, write, and return each of three examination essays. These are completed within a two-week period. Students must pass the written portions of the exam before proceeding to the oral examination. The oral exam takes place within fifteen days of successful completion of the written components and lasts between two and three hours.</p>
<p><em>The Dissertation</em><br />
A dissertation is expected to make an original and substantial contribution to the student’s particular field knowledge and specialization. It is a work of connected expository prose presenting the discovery of new information; the combination or synthesis of previously unconnected facts; production of new interpretations of cultural material; application of theory to literary, linguistic, artistic, cultural or historical phenomena; extension of methodology characteristic of a particular discipline into the subject area of some other discipline or disciplines; or some combination of any or all of the above.</p>
<p>The full description of the Ph.D. program degree requirements, including explicit policies and procedures are detailed in the Graduate Program Handbook.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-461 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->

<article id="post-459" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Admission</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The best prepared applicants to the M.A./Ph.D. program in Scandinavian will have a strong knowledge of one Scandinavian language, a good reading ability in at least one other Scandinavian language, excellent writing skills, and knowledge of the broad outline of Scandinavian literary, cultural, and intellectual history. Students with deficiencies in any of these areas may also be considered, especially if they have clearly taken measures to address gaps in the profile. The department is also ready to entertain program proposals from applicants with special interests in areas such as art and history as long as the primary interests are literary. Completion of an official undergraduate major in Scandinavian Studies is not required for admission to the graduate program as long as the functional language and research skills necessary for graduate-seminar work are in place at the start of graduate studies.</p>
<p>When preparing to apply, students should articulate a research statement of interest that makes clear the intersection of the student’s interests with those of the department faculty, the student’s motivation for graduate study, and a possible field of research emphasis.</p>
<p>The average time to Ph.D. degree completion for students entering the Scandinavian graduate program is six-seven years, including all phases of M.A. and Ph.D. coursework, exams, and dissertation research and writing. Time in the program will be shorter for those entering with an equivalent M.A. degree in Scandinavian or a closely related field.</p>
<p><strong>International applicants:</strong> It is important for students applying from abroad to realize that Berkeley is a public university and that student support funding structures limit the number of international applicants that can be considered for admission. Nevertheless, international applicants with very strong academic records and research interests appropriate to our program are encouraged to apply if they are willing to pursue the broad comparative training in Scandinavian topics that our program provides. Of special note: Students accepted from abroad cannot enter the program to work directly on dissertation research, but must first complete the required coursework and Qualifying Exam before being advanced to Ph.D. candidacy.</p>
<p><strong>Instructions for applying:</strong></p>
<p>The admissions process for the Department of Scandinavian graduate program runs on an annual basis, with each year&#8217;s online applications generally becoming available in early September and a submissions deadline in early January. Applications cannot be considered off-cycle. We do not accept applications for an M.A.-only degree program. Detailed application instructions can be found here: <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Scandi-applicant-instruction-web-1.pdf">Application Instructions</a>.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-459 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->

" alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

<header id="site-header" class="home wideness" role="banner">
		<div class="upper-field">
		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Livet forstås baglæns, men må leves forlæns.</div>

	 </div>

<article id="post-950" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Graduate Placement</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The Department of Scandinavian has an excellent track record in the placement of recent Ph.Ds in teaching and other professional positions. Dissertation topics range from medieval to modern, from the strictly literary and historical to more interdisciplinary subjects. Since 1990, Scandinavian Department students have produced the following dissertations and have been hired in the following positions:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Ben Bigelow</strong>, Ph.D. 2017<br />
Currently: Assistant Professor of Scandinavian Studies, Department of German, Scandinavian, and Dutch, University of Minnesota &#8211; Twin Cities</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Jenna Coughlin</strong>, Ph.D. 2017<br />
Dissertation: <em>Conceptions of Nature in </em>Nynorsk<em> Poetry: Local Language and Situated Nature Knowledge in Ivar Aasen, Olav Nygard, and Tarjei and Halldis Moren Vesaas</em><br />
Currently: Lecturer, Department of Scandinavian, University of California, Berkeley</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Monica Hidalgo</strong>, Ph.D. 2015<br />
Dissertation:<em> (Dis)orienting the Reader: Literary Impressionism and the Case of Herman Bang</em><br />
Currently: Lecturer, Department of Scandinavian, University of California, Berkeley</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Erik Schjeide</strong>, Ph.D. 2015 Dissertation: <em>Crafting Words and Wood: Myth, Carving and</em> Húsdrápa<br />
Currently: Independent Scholar</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Verena Hoefig</strong>, Ph.D. 2014<br />
Dissertation: <em>Finding a Founding Father: Memory, Identity and the Icelandic </em>landnám<br />
Currently: Assistant Professor of Medieval Studies, Department of Germanic Languages and Literatures, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Molly Jacobs Bauer</strong>, Ph.D. 2014<br />
Dissertation: <em>A Most Splendid Tree&#8217;: Hákon Hákonarson and the Norwegian Royal Court as a Site of Literary Production</em><br />
Currently: Independent Scholar</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Benjamin Mier-Cruz</strong>, Ph.D. 2013<br />
Dissertation: <em>Edith Södergran&#8217;s Modern Virgin: Overcoming Nietzsche and the Gendered Narrator</em><br />
Currently: Instructor of Swedish and Scandinavian, Department of German and Scandinavian, University of Oregon</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Elisabeth Ida Ward</strong>, Ph.D. 2012<br />
Dissertation: <em>Nested Narrative: </em>Þórðar saga hreðu <em>and Material Engagement</em><br />
Currently: Executive Director of the Los Altos History Museum</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Amanda Doxtater</strong>, Ph.D. 2012<br />
Dissertation: <em>Pathos, Performance, Volition: Melodrama&#8217;s Legacy in the Work of Carl Th. Dreyer</em><br />
Currently: Assistant Professor of Scandinavian Studies, Department of Scandinavian Studies, University of Washington</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Dean Krouk</strong>, Ph.D. 2011<br />
Dissertation: <em>Catastrophes of Redemption: Modernism and Fascism in Norway</em><br />
Currently: Assistant Professor, Department of Scandinavian Studies, University of Wisconsin, Madison</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Suzanne Martin</strong>, Ph.D. 2010<br />
Dissertation: <em>Alla människor har sin berättelse: Interculturalism, Intermediality and the Trope of Testimony in Novels by Ekman, Ørstavik and Petersen</em><br />
Currently: Active as freelance Swedish-English translator</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Carl Olsen</strong>, Ph.D. 2009<br />
Dissertation: <em>Ekphrasis and the Old Norse Shield Poem</em><br />
Currently: Visiting Assistant Professor, Department of Scandinavian, Gustavus Adolphus College</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Nichole Sterling</strong>, Ph.D. 2008<br />
Dissertation: <em>The Other Side: Icelandic Identity and Foreigners in the Islendingasogur</em><br />
Currently: Attorney, Cahill Gordon &amp; Reindel</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>David Gantt Gurley</strong>, Ph.D. 2007<br />
Dissertation: <em>Meir Aaron Goldschmidt and the Poetics of Prose</em><br />
Currently: Assistant Professor, Department of German and Scandinavian, University of Oregon</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Kendra Willson</strong>, Ph.D. 2007<br />
Dissertation: <em>Icelandic Nicknames</em><br />
Currently: Researcher, Helsinki Collegium for Advanced Study</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Hanne Pico Larsen</strong>, Ph.D. 2006<br />
Dissertation: <em>Solvang, the &#8216;Danish Capital of America&#8217;: A Little Bit of Denmark, Disney, or Something Else</em><br />
Currently: Assistant Professor, Department of Marketing, Copenhagen Business School</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Merrill Kaplan</strong>, Ph.D. 2006<br />
Dissertation: <em>The Irruption of the Past in four texts in Flateyjarbók</em><br />
Currently: Associate Professor, Departments of English and Germanic Languages and Literatures, The Ohio State University</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Christopher Oscarson</strong>, Ph.D. 2006<br />
Dissertation: <em>Landscape and the Entangled Bird&#8217;s Eye View: Turn of the 20th Century Swedish Culture and the Ecological Imaginary</em><br />
Currently: Associate Professor, Scandinavian Program, Brigham Young University</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Michael Durwin Coleman</strong>, Ph.D. 2005<br />
Dissertation: <em>Media(ting) Jenny Lind: Representing Celebrity in Nineteenth Century Sweden</em><br />
Currently: Senior Learning and Development Consultant, Wells Fargo Wealth Management Group</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Brigid Gaffikin</strong>, Ph.D. 2005<br />
Dissertation: <em>Fiction and Materiality in Han Christian Andersen&#8217;s Travel Writing</em><br />
Currently: Freelance writer and editor</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Sonia Wichmann</strong>, Ph.D. 2005<br />
Dissertation: <em>Truths About Women: Self-Representation as Fiction and Testimony in the Diaries of Victoria Benedictsson, Aino Kallas, and Elin Wagner</em><br />
Currently: President of the Northern California Translators Association.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Valdimar Tr. Hafstein</strong>, Ph.D. 2004<br />
Dissertation: <em>The Making of Intangible Cultural Heritage: Tradition and Authenticity, Community and Humanity</em><br />
Currently: Professor, Department of Anthropology and Folklore at the University of Iceland</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Arne Lunde</strong>, Ph.D. 2003<br />
Dissertation: <em>Nordic Exposures: Scandinavian Whiteness and Ethnic Assimilation in Classical Hollywood Cinema</em>.<br />
Currently: Associate Professor, Scandinavian Section, UCLA</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Stephanie Buus</strong>, Ph.D. 2002<br />
Dissertation: <em>Travel, Translation, and Self in Scandinavian Travel Accounts of the Napoleonic Era</em></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Elisabeth Oxfeldt</strong>, Ph.D. 2002<br />
Dissertation: <em>Orientalism on the Periphery: The Cosmopolitan Imagination in Nineteenth-Century Danish and Norwegian Literature and Culture</em><br />
Currently: Professor of Norwegian at the University of Oslo</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Ulla Thomsen</strong>, Ulla, Ph.D. 2002<br />
Dissertation: <em>Familie-Tidende: A Portrayal of Danish Women&#8217;s Rights in 1871</em></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Michael Jay Stern</strong>, Ph.D. 2000<br />
Dissertation: <em>Strindberg&#8217;s Encounter with Nietzsche: The Conflation of Autobiography and History</em><br />
Currently: Associate Professor, Department of German and Scandinavian, University of Oregon</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Ebba Filippa Segerberg</strong>, Ph.D. 1999<br />
Dissertation: <em>Nostalgia, Narrative, and Modernity in Swedish Silent Cinema</em><br />
Currently: Director of Communications for Arts and Sciences, Washington University, St. Louis; Literary translator</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Charles Maxwell Olmstead</strong>, Ph.D. 1998<br />
Dissertation: <em>An Introduction to Oddr Snorrason&#8217;s &#8216;Óláfs saga Tryggvasonar</em>&#8216;<br />
Currently: Pastor of Higganum Congregational Church, Higganum, Connecticut since 2004.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Zoe Patrice Borovsky</strong>, Ph.D. 1994<br />
Dissertation: <em>Rocking the Boat: Women in Old Norse Literature</em><br />
Currently: Librarian for Digital Research and Scholarship, UCLA</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Monika Zagar</strong>, Ph.D. 1994<br />
Dissertation: <em>Ideological Clowns in the Fiction of Dag Solstad</em><br />
Currently: Professor, Department of German, Scandinavian, and Dutch, University of Minnesota</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Timothy Roland Tangherlini</strong>, Ph.D. 1992<br />
Dissertation: <em>Interpreting Legend: Evald Tang Kristensen&#8217;s Legend Informants and their Repertoires</em><br />
Currently: Professor, Scandinavian Section, UCLA</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Mark Bennion Sandberg</strong>, Ph.D. 1991<br />
Dissertation: <em>Missing Persons: Spectacle and Narrative in Late Nineteenth-Century Scandinavia</em><br />
Currently: Professor, Department of Scandinavian and Department of Film and Media, UC-Berkeley</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Marianne Stecher Hansen</strong>, Ph.D. 1990<br />
Dissertation: <em>Thorkild Hansen and Historical Narrative: A Study of Narrative Technique in </em>Det lykkelige Arabien <em>and</em> Jens Munk<br />
Currently: Professor, Department of Scandinavian Studies, University of Washington</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-950 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->

<article id="post-815" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Graduate Handbook</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The Graduate Student Handbook for the Department of Scandinavian is the consolidated reference resource for continuing graduate students in the department. It contains the most detailed and recent statement of official departmental and divisional policies relevant to progress through the M.A. and Ph.D. programs, and students are encouraged to consult it regularly. For the most recent version of the handbook, click <strong><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/2017-18-handbook.pdf">here</a></strong>.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-815 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/programs.jpg" class="tooltip" title="The &ldquo;ant chair&rdquo; gets its name from the thorax shape of the back and seat, and was designed in 1952 by the influential Danish architect and designer Arne Jacobsen (1902-71) to be modular, light, and easily stackable. " alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Valr lá þar á sandi<br />
vitinn inum eineygja<br />
Friggjar faðmbyggvi;<br />
fǫgnuðum dáð slíkri.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					The slain lay there on the sand,<br />
dedicated to the one-eyed<br />
embrace-occupier of Frigg;<br />
we welcomed such doings. <br />
(Old Norse)				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Hrafnsmál, Stanza 12</span>
				
			</a>

<article id="post-465" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Interdisciplinary Programs</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p><strong>Medieval Studies</strong></p>
<p>The interdisciplinary graduate group in Medieval Studies provides intellectual interaction between faculty and graduate students in a variety of UCB departments that feature medieval studies within their individual curricula. Graduate students already accepted and enrolled in a home department can also apply to the Medieval Studies Concurrent Ph.D. program. More detailed information on the interdisciplinary program in Medieval Studies can be found <a href="http://medieval.berkeley.edu/"><em>here</em></a>.</p>
<p><strong>Designated Emphasis programs</strong></p>
<p>The UCB Graduate Division allows students accepted and enrolled in a home department to pursue a Designated Emphasis (essentially, a graduate minor) in an approved interdisciplinary field. Each Designated Emphasis has its own requirements, but usually requires several core courses and representation from the relevant faculty on both the exam and dissertation committees. The Designated Emphasis programs listed below are those that have typically been of interest to our students; please consult each website for detailed descriptions and requirements. (It is assumed that students who are considering one of these options will have discussed their plans with the department&#8217;s current Graduate Adviser early enough in their graduate careers so as not to unduly delay their time to degree.)</p>
<p><a href="http://criticaltheory.berkeley.edu/"><em>The Designated Emphasis in Critical Theory</em></a>: The DE in Critical Theory permits interested students to specialize in critical theory, and to obtain certification of this specialization, while pursuing a Ph.D. in an established UC Berkeley Department. Critical Theory is not an independent degree granting program. Students admitted to the DE and completing the requirements will receive a parenthetical notation to that effect on their doctoral degrees.</p>
<p><a href="http://filmmedia.berkeley.edu/programs/graduate-program/graduate-designated-emphasis"><em>Designated Emphasis in Film</em> <em>Studies</em></a>: The Designated Emphasis in Film Studies provides curricular and research resources for students who want to concentrate on film within their respective disciplines and have their work formally recognized. Applicants to this program must have completed one seminar in the Department of Film and Media at the time of application and must fulfill specific course, Qualifying Exam, and Dissertation Committee requirements if admitted to the program.</p>
<p><a href="http://folklore.berkeley.edu/programs/de.php"><em>Designated Emphasis in Folklore</em></a>: Students receiving degrees from other departments may now declare a designated emphasis in Folklore Studies. The designated emphasis is designed to complement core PhD programs and provides exciting opportunities for interdisciplinary study and cross-collaboration.</p>
<p><a href="http://rems.berkeley.edu/"><em>The Designated Emphasis in Renaissance and Early Modern Studies</em></a>: offers comprehensive training in intellectual and cultural history, material culture, and languages of the Renaissance and Early Modern periods.</p>
<p><a href="http://womensstudies.berkeley.edu/graduate/detail"><em>The Designated Emphasis Program in Women, Gender, and Sexuality</em></a>: This is an interdisciplinary program available to students who are already admitted to a graduate program at University of California, Berkeley. Taken in conjunction with Ph.D. programs in the Humanities and Social Sciences, the Designated Emphasis provides opportunities for interdisciplinary study with more than 30 faculty across the campus.</p>
<p><a href="http://bcnm.berkeley.edu/index.php/designated-emphasis-program/"><em>The Designated Emphasis in New Media</em></a>:  BCNM’s Designated Emphasis (D.E.) program is for selected UC Berkeley Ph.D. students from any Berkeley home department with research interests in new media. It is supplemental to the Ph.D. program in the regular departments, and provides enhanced skills in analyzing and/or designing future media with an awareness of historical, social, cultural, and other perspectives that might not be visible from any single disciplinary point of view.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-465 -->

										</div>

<div id="wrapper" class="hfeed">
	
<header id="site-header" class="home wideness" role="banner">
		<div class="upper-field">
		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Gift Dig, Du vil fortryde det; gift Dig ikke, Du vil ogsaa fortryde det.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					Marry and you will regret it; do not marry, and you will also regret it. (Danish)				</div>

<article id="post-463" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Financial Support</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The department limits the number of graduate students admitted to those it can support with multiple-year financial packages that combine university fellowships, department grants, and employment as a Graduate Student Instructor. Some of these funding sources are awarded at the time of admission, and others are reserved for the dissertation phase of the program. In addition to the main sources of annual support guaranteed in advance at the time of admission, smaller grants targeted to specific travel needs for research or conference presentations are awarded on an annual basis.</p>
<h2 class="anchored-header">Departmental Support</h2>
<p><strong>Department Fellowships</strong><br />
The department sometimes supports incoming students with available internal funding at a level comparable to an annual GSI salary.</p>
<p><strong>Departmental Librarian Position</strong><br />
Students can also be assigned a position as Department Librarian, which provides the equivalent of an annual GSI salary.</p>
<p><strong>Graduate Student Instructor Positions</strong></p>
<p><em>Language Teaching</em>:<br />
The department can appoint students with the necessary language fluency in a modern Scandinavian language to an instructor position teaching both beginning and intermediate classes. Training in language pedagogy is required and provided by the department.</p>
<p><em>Reading and Composition Teaching</em>:<br />
Students are also given opportunities to teach courses in the university’s Reading and Composition sequence by choosing topics of their own interest together with Scandinavian texts taught in translation. Additional campus training in college-writing pedagogy is also required in conjunction with these assignments.<br />
R&amp;C assignments for experienced instructors are also available each summer in the UCB Summer Sessions as a way to earn extra income in addition to the annual student support packages.</p>
<p>The qualifications for appointment to a Graduate Student Instructor position can be found <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Scandi_GSI_Desc-6-18-2015.pdf"><em>here</em></a>.</p>
<p><strong>Graduate Student Researcher positions</strong><br />
Individual department faculty members at times have research funding available to hire graduate students to aid with their ongoing research projects. These appointments can under certain conditions be combined with other positions.</p>
<p><strong>Readerships</strong><br />
Faculty undergraduate courses with high enrollments can qualify for funds to hire course Readers to assist faculty instructors with the grading of papers and assignments. Paid duties include hours spent in attendance, reading, or grading, but Readers do not supervise discussion sections or hold office hours.</p>
<p><strong>Research and Professional Travel Funding</strong><br />
The department has some limited funds available to support student travel and participation in language programs, conferences (including teacher workshops), and individual research projects. Partial funding of travel to the annual SASS conference is guaranteed for those presenting papers, and requests for that funding should be folded into the annual continuing student funding application (see below), but for other travel opportunities related to professional development, students can apply off-cycle using <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/conference-travel-application.docx"><em>this form</em></a>.</p>
<p><strong>Application Procedures:</strong></p>
<p>For continuing graduate students in the Department of Scandinavian:<br />
There is an annual application cycle for continued funding in which each student is required to complete an updated application each February. The most recent version of the application form can be found <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/15-16.support.application.docx"><em>here</em></a>, and the general instructions for filling out the form <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/How-to-Apply-for-Funding.pdf"><em>here</em></a>.</p>
<p>For students enrolled in other UCB graduate programs:<br />
Graduate Student Instructor assignments made for the regular academic year are generally reserved for Department of Scandinavian graduate students since they serve as a form of departmental financial support. Even so, there are occasionally teaching opportunities available during the year and especially in Summer Sessions for those students outside the department with the required teacher training and experience with Scandinavian literary or filmic materials. Interested students should apply to the current faculty Graduate Adviser with a CV and statement of interest.</p>
<h2 class="anchored-header">University Support</h2>
<p><strong>University Fellowships upon admission</strong><br />
Incoming students with superior academic records may be nominated during the admissions process to a university-wide selection committee for consideration for multi-year fellowships. If awarded, these fellowships may form part of an admitted student’s overall multi-year support package; otherwise, a combination of departmental funding and teaching appointments will form the basis for a student&#8217;s financial support package.</p>
<p><strong>Graduate Division Conference Travel Grants</strong><br />
Ph.D. and Master’s students in academic degree programs may apply for funding to attend professional conferences. Grant amounts will depend on the location of the conference (up to $400 within California, $600 elsewhere in North America, including Canada or Mexico, and $1,000 outside of North America. Master’s students are eligible for only one conference travel grant per academic career. Doctoral students are eligible for two grants per graduate career, regardless of how many degrees they earn. To be eligible to apply, applicants must be registered for the term in which they are planning to attend the conference (students on filing fee are not eligible); be in good academic standing; and be presenting a paper or poster at the conference. The application for these travel grants can be found <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Grad-Div-travel_grants.pdf"><em>here</em></a>.</p>
<p><strong>Fritz O. Fernström Fellowship</strong><br />
The Department of Scandinavian administers the Fritz O. Fernström Fellowship program on behalf of the university. The terms of the endowment state “preference shall be given to American students who wish to study in Scandinavia, preferably Sweden, and to students in Scandinavian Languages and Literature,” but the evaluation committee uses a wide definition of Scandinavia and encourages applications from current qualified graduate students in all fields at UC-Berkeley. The fellowship as now administered is thus intended to support short-term or year-long research or study that requires travel to any of the Nordic countries (Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, or Sweden). Past awards have been made to students from Architecture, Rhetoric, Music, Political Science, Art, Sociology, Energy &amp; Resources, and Computer Science, as well as to students from the Department of Scandinavian. Students must be U.S. citizens or Permanent Residents, and must be currently registered graduate students at UCB. Applications are evaluated in an annual competition with an application deadline that usually falls in mid-February. Selection criteria include the overall strength of the academic record and faculty recommendations, the degree of preparation (including language competency, when relevant to the project), the expected intellectual contribution of the project to research in the applicant&#8217;s field, and the feasibility of the plan given the described methodology and resources. Successful applications demonstrate the need for research or study in a Scandinavian country that cannot be accomplished elsewhere, or relevance of the language and/or culture to the student’s dissertation topic. Demonstrated effort at finding support from multiple sources also counts in an applicant’s favor. Award amounts have averaged approximately $3750 over the past 10 years, including both short and longer-term stays abroad (students looking for year-long support may also combine Fernström funding with other sources). Applications to support advanced language study or conference attendance may also be considered when that study is crucial to a specific research plan. Requested budgets may be adjusted in the final awards. Current deadlines and the most recent application form can be found <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/fernstr%C3%B6m-application.web_.docx"><span class="s2"><i>here</i></span></a>.</p>
<p><strong>Doctoral Completion Fellowship</strong><br />
Beginning with the students who began graduate study in Fall 2010, all those who have officially advanced to PhD candidacy (having passed their Qualifying Exams) are offered a two-semester stipend of $18,000 plus fees (and non-resident tuition for international students) as incentive for completing the dissertation within the normative time (defined for the Scandinavian as seven years total in the program). Students who receive this fellowship agree that they will not be eligible to receive any form of University funding (including teaching assignments, department block grant, and travel and research support) after the completion of their seventh year of study.</p>
<p><strong>UC Dissertation-Year Fellowships</strong><br />
The UC Office of the President sponsors this dissertation-year fellowship program for Berkeley students. Awards currently include a living stipend of $20,500, payment of fees, and a travel allowance. Eligibility criteria for this dissertation include: experience of situations or conditions which were an impediment to advancing to graduate study; the pursuit of academic research interests focusing on cultural, societal or educational problems as they affect educationally disadvantaged segments of society; or evidence of intention to use the doctoral degree toward serving educationally underrepresented segments of society. A more detailed description of the program and a recent application can be found <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/uc_dissyear_application.pdf"><em>here</em></a>.</p>
<p><strong>Townsend Dissertation Fellowships</strong><br />
This fellowship is intended to further the research of Ph.D candidates through interdisciplinary discussion with student and faculty colleagues in other disciplines and departments. Awards are based on the scholarly merit of the individual applications. Projects need not be &#8220;interdisciplinary&#8221; by definition, but are evaluated in part by their potential interest for interdisciplinary discussion. Townsend Graduate Student Fellows receive an $18,000 stipend, and the Townsend Center will also provide payment of fees depending on the availability of funds. Effective September 1, 2011, Townsend Dissertation Fellows may combine fellowship awards up to the maximum amount set by the Graduate Division, but since the purpose of the Townsend Fellowship is to enable full-time research, Townsend Fellows are not eligible to teach or hold other academic appointments during the fellowship year. More information about the award can be found <a href="http://townsendcenter.berkeley.edu/funding/townsend-dissertation-fellowships"><em>here</em></a>.</p>
<p><strong>Maternity/Paternity support and accommodation</strong><br />
The Graduate Division administers a need-based grant for graduate students (single, married, or registered domestic partners) living with dependent children. Grants may be applied toward housing/living expenses, dependent health insurance, child care, and/or tuition. If funding permits, awards of up to $8,000 per year ($4,000 per academic term) will be made to eligible applicants. An example of a recent application form can be found <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/parent_grant_app.pdf"><em>here</em></a>.</p>
<p>For an updated list of other university sources of graduate financial support and the most current application deadlines and forms, consult the Graduate Division <a href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/financial/fellowships/">Fellowships and Grants</a> website.</p>
<h2 class="anchored-header">Extramural Funding Sources</h2>
<p>The following are suggested funding sources outside the university that are of particular interest to graduate students studying in the Department of Scandinavian. Most of them express a preference for dissertation-stage students in their selection criteria, but please consult each website for more detailed information.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.amscan.org/grants_americans.html"><em>American-Scandinavian Foundation Fellowships</em></a></p>
<p>The American-Scandinavian Foundation administers an annual fellowship competition in all academic and artistic fields for American scholars to pursue study, research, or artistic projects in any of the five Nordic countries.</p>
<p><a href="http://us.fulbrightonline.org/countries/selectedregion/21"><em>Fulbright U.S. Student Program</em></a></p>
<p>The Fulbright U.S. Student Program provides grants for individually designed study/research projects or for English Teaching Assistant Programs. A candidate will submit a <em>Statement of Grant Purpose</em> defining activities to take place during one academic year in a participating country outside the U.S.</p>
<p><em><a href="http://www.scandinavianstudy.org/site/index.php?option=com_content&amp;view=article&amp;id=57&amp;Itemid=62">Birgit Baldwin Fellowship in Scandinavian Studies</a><br />
</em></p>
<p>The Society for the Advancement of Scandinavian Study (SASS) is responsible for an annual fellowship competition for dissertation students in the fields of Scandinavian (Nordic) literature or film that can most effectively be pursued in the archives and libraries of the Nordic countries.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.scandinavianstudy.org/site/index.php?option=com_content&amp;view=article&amp;id=88&amp;Itemid=70"><em>The Einar and Eva Lund Haugen Memorial Scholarship</em></a></p>
<p>The scholarship is intended to support outstanding graduate students whose doctoral dissertation examines a Scandinavian or Scandinavian-American topic in the Social Sciences or History, broadly defined. SASS administers this scholarship competition.</p>
<p>SWEA</p>
<p>The Swedish Women&#8217;s Educational Association (SWEA) is a worldwide organization that offers two doctoral research scholarships of $10,000 through the SWEA <a href="http://litstip.swea.org/litteraturstipendiet/">Litteraturstipendiet</a> program. Applicants should be an accomplished doctoral student at a university outside Sweden pursuing research in Swedish language, literature, or society.</p>
<p>The local San Francisco chapter of SWEA also runs its own <a href="http://sanfrancisco.swea.org/scholarship/">fellowship competition</a> for an award in the amount of $7500. It is intended to be awarded to a qualified individual or group in the Western United States who is pursuing academic or professional research or artistic endeavors with particular relevance to Sweden. The candidate’s project may include, but is not limited to, work in areas such as Swedish culture, history, music, visual or performing arts, literature, media, sciences, or the environment. It is expected that the project will result in a tangible product and will be completed within a year of receipt of the award. The final outcome of the project should be of a kind that can be shared with other interested groups or parties to help spread knowledge about Sweden abroad.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.leifureirikssonfoundation.org/scholarship/"><em>Leifur Eiríksson Foundation Scholarship</em></a></p>
<p>These scholarships are intended for students at U.S. universities to pursue graduate study or research at Icelandic universities.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-463 -->

<article id="post-455" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">B.A. Program</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The undergraduate curriculum in Scandinavian is a liberal-arts programs that trains students in language skills, critical thinking and writing, and cultural understanding. It provides a broad competence in the history, literature, and cultural achievements of the Nordic region, from medieval to modern times, and can serve as a first step to careers in writing, translation, editing, or business, especially those in which ties to the Nordic region are important.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-455 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



<div class="image-key wideness"><img src="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/wp-content/themes/scandinavian/images/keys/programs.jpg" class="tooltip" title="The &ldquo;ant chair&rdquo; gets its name from the thorax shape of the back and seat, and was designed in 1952 by the influential Danish architect and designer Arne Jacobsen (1902-71) to be modular, light, and easily stackable. " alt=""></div>
	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

			<div class="initial-quote">Ef allir hlutir í heiminum, kykvir ok dauðir, gráta hann, þá skal hann fara til Ása aptr.</div>

					If all things in the world, living as well as dead, cry for him, he shall return to the Æsir. (Old Norse) 				</div>

<article id="post-620" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Awards, Scholarships, and Grants</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p><em>Awards</em></p>
<p>At commencement each year, there are two awards the Department of Scandinavian can make to deserving students majoring in Scandinavian:</p>
<ul>
<li>The first, the Departmental Citation, can be given to one student each year who has done outstanding academic work (minimum GPA of 3.5) in either the Scandinavian or Celtic Studies major.</li>
<li>The second, the Lundberg Prize, is a Department of Scandinavian award recognizing excellence in scholarship by a graduating senior who has majored in Scandinavian. This prize was offered for the first time in 2013.</li>
</ul>
<p>Recent Scandinavian Department award recipients include:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px">2013-14 Severin Martinez (Lundberg)<br />
2013-14 Holly Kane (Citation)<br />
2012-13 Kailey Willmore (Lundberg)<br />
2009-10 Genevieve Thurston (Citation)<br />
2007-08 Linda Nyberg (Citation)<br />
2005-06 Lindsie Goss (Citation)<br />
2003-04 Gary Duncan (Citation)<br />
2002-03 Marie Mathiesen (Citation)<br />
2001-02 Rachel Fox (Citation)<br />
2000-01 Elizabeth Stokkebye (Citation)</p>
<p><em>Undergraduate Scholarships</em></p>
<p><a href="http://scandinavian.wisc.edu/schmidt/danish/Gudrun_Gytel.htm">Gudrun Gytel Fund Scholarships</a><br />
The Gudrun Gytel Fund was established in 1998 in order to provide qualified American University students with the opportunity to further their knowledge of Danish culture, history, language, literature, politics and society. The scholarship supports semester or academic year-long study at recognized Danish institutions of higher education in the fields of humanities and social sciences, as well as in architecture, engineering, technology and related fields.</p>
<p><em>Undergraduate Travel Grants</em></p>
<p><strong>James I. Healy Undergraduate Travel Fund</strong><br />
The Healy travel fund was established in 2007 through a generous donation from James Healy, who received a B.A. in Scandinavian in 1990. The amount of the award is flexible, and can be used to support travel by currently enrolled UC-Berkeley undergraduates to Scandinavian countries in order to further their study of Scandinavian languages and cultures, with a preference for Danish. Preference will be given to students returning to campus after studying abroad to complete their final semester at Berkeley, but students completing major requirements abroad will also be considered with prior faculty advisor permission. Interested students should submit an unofficial transcript and a 1-2 page, single-spaced statement of purpose to the current Undergraduate Faculty Adviser by <strong>February 1</strong>, with awards targeted for use the following summer or academic year. The statement should note the departmental courses taken so far, the relevant details of the study-abroad program, and the importance of the targeted program for the intended course of study. NOTE: Undergraduate awards may or may not affect University financial aid status. Documentation of travel and study in a Scandinavian country, as well as a summary report of the experience, will be required for all awardees.</p>
<p>Past recipients of the Healy Travel Grant include:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px">Douglas Blue (2011, Danish/Scandinavian Minor)<br />
Genevieve Thurston (2009, Danish/Scandinavian Major)</p>
<p><strong>Lundberg Travel Grant</strong><br />
Beginning in the academic year 2015-16, the Department of Scandinavian encourages students who have taken coursework in the department to apply for grants to subsidize travel to study-abroad programs anywhere in the Nordic region, either for summer or semester-long programs. One Lundberg Travel Grant in the amount of $1500 will be available each year in this competition. The deadline is <strong>February 1</strong> each year (applications cannot be considered off-cycle), and applicants should not have more than junior-year standing at that time (awards are targeted for use the following summer or academic year). Interested students should submit an unofficial transcript and a 1-2 page, single-spaced statement of purpose to the current Undergraduate Faculty Adviser by that deadline, together with this <a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Lundberg-Travel-Grant-Form.docx">application form</a>. The statement should note the departmental courses taken so far, the relevant details of the study-abroad program, and the importance of the targeted program for the intended course of study. Preference will be given to Scandinavian majors, but all who have taken a minimum of two courses in the department (including enrollments current at the time of application) are eligible for the competition. NOTE: Undergraduate awards may or may not affect University financial aid status. Documentation of travel and study in a Scandinavian country will be required for all awardees.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-620 -->

										</div>

		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Þat eru bókrúnar, <br />
þat eru bjargrúnar,<br />
ok allar ǫlrúnar,<br />
ok mætar meginrúnar.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					That is book-runes, <br />
that is birth-runes, <br />
and all ale-runes, <br />
and the famed power-runes.<br />
(Old Norse)				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Sigrdrífumál, stanza 19</span>
				
			</a>

<article id="post-591" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Double Majoring in Scandinavian</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p><em>Did you know?</em></p>
<p>Freshmen entering with Advanced Placement enrichment courses taken in high school are in a perfect position to pursue a double major while attending UC Berkeley. These credited units used to satisfy University requirements do not have to be counted towards the 120-130 unit maximum for the Bachelor’s Degree, allowing students to remain at Berkeley for a full eight semesters while acquiring two majors.</p>
<p>An early start to language study during one’s freshman or sophomore year is key to allowing sufficient time to acquire the four semesters of language courses required for each of the five concentrations within the Scandinavian major. Elementary language sequences in Danish, Finnish, Norwegian, and Swedish begin each fall and can be applied to the chosen major concentration in the language and culture of one Nordic country. A concentration in Old Norse Studies has more flexibility in the second year of language study, including options for using first-year instruction of Danish, Norwegian, or Swedish <em>or</em> two semesters of elementary Icelandic <em>or</em> two semesters of elementary Latin (Latin 1 and 2) when combined with a year of coursework in beginning Old Norse.</p>
<p>In general, up to two courses can be double-counted towards requirements in two different major programs at Berkeley depending how closely related the major requirements are. Essentially, two courses can count as four, making it easier to double major. In addition, there are several majors at UC Berkeley (such as Political Economy or Peace and Conflict Studies) that require four semesters of lower-division language, which may also be applied (with permission of the other major program) to lower-division language requirements within the Scandinavian major. With four courses overlapping between two majors, the double major becomes a clear possibility. Students in Classics, Medieval Studies, or other major programs that emphasize the study of Latin will also find it easier to fit in a double major in Old Norse Studies by utilizing Latin 1 and 2 coursework for this concentration.</p>
<p><em>Why Two Majors?</em></p>
<p>Berkeley is a unique learning environment with a diversity of majors, curricula, research, and study-abroad opportunities. Students double-majoring in Scandinavian also study in fields as far-ranging as the environmental sciences, biological sciences, history of art, mathematics, business, history, comparative literature, and architecture, among many others. Many of our double majors pursue a balance between fulfilling career goals and feeding their intellectual and personal interests in the study of the language and culture of the Nordic world, a region that has brought significant contributions in areas such as environmental studies, international studies, peace and diplomacy, public policy, political science, architecture, design, economics, medieval literature, folklore, history, drama, film and linguistics.</p>
<p><em>Have we given you something to think about?</em></p>
<p>Early planning is the key. Your next step is to see our undergraduate advisor!</p>
<p><em>Who to Talk to</em>:</p>
<p><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/amanda-minafo/">Amanda Minafo</a><br />
Undergraduate Student Services Advisor</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-591 -->

										</div>

<article id="post-595" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Goals and Assessment</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The Undergraduate Student Learning Initiative (USLI) is a campuswide project that has been under development at Berkeley since Fall 2007. This initiative is designed to promote and facilitate learning for undergraduates across campus. As part of this initiative, the Scandinavian Department faculty has articulated learning goals in the Scandinavian major and minor and suggested pathways to reach those goals.</p>
<p><em>Learning goals for the Scandinavian major</em></p>
<p>Communicative competence in one of the modern Nordic languages (Danish, Finnish, Norwegian, and Swedish), in both the spoken and written language within a cultural context (please note special requirements for Finnish, below), or in the case of the Old Norse Studies concentration, reading competence in Old Norse;<br />
Understanding of the linguistic, historical, and cultural relationships that join and divide the nations and peoples of the Nordic region;<br />
Understanding the broad trajectory of Nordic literary culture from the Middle Ages to contemporary times, including both canonical works and works from the margins;<br />
Mastery of research and analytical skills sufficient to enable the student to understand received wisdom and new scholarship, and to draw insightful and original conclusions about literature, film, folklore, art history, and other aspects of literary culture;<br />
Writing and reasoning skills (mounting a persuasive argument, marshalling and synthesizing appropriate evidence, crafting syntactically correct, carefully documented essays and oral presentations).</p>
<p>One of the unique aspects of Nordic literary studies is the close relationship among the countries and their languages (excepting Finnish, which is not linguistically related to the Scandinavian languages). Students majoring in our discipline, while developing competence in one of the languages, are expected to take cultural courses (taught in translation) that extend across national boundaries so that they develop knowledge of the region as a whole. There are courses that are limited to an authorship within one national literature (Andersen, Bergman, Ibsen, Strindberg, for example), but students are expected to take courses outside their area of language competence as many of our courses are pan-Scandinavian in focus.</p>
<p>We assess the achievement of modern-language skills in written and oral examinations and writing assignments within the context of individual courses. The modern language courses require the assessment of both oral and written skills. Students are assessed orally for their mastery of specific communicative acts at a particular threshold (according to ACTFL proficiency guidelines): for example, correct use of appropriate vocabulary and verb tense, awareness of syntax, knowledge of time expressions, idioms, plural forms, etc. Written assessment centers on the same knowledge but requires students to use a more extensive vocabulary and stretch the range of their expression. Part of the writing process includes learning to use reference tools and libraries.</p>
<p>Students in literature and culture courses write research papers as well as comprehensive written examinations. Majors in the discipline take two individual tutorials designed to strengthen language and analytical skills with faculty members. The tutorials are offered in conjunction with an upper-division literature course, but require that readings be done in the original language. Faculty members teaching these tutorials assess the level of language competency through oral communication during the tutorial, when appropriate, and through written assignments in the original language. Majors in the discipline are encouraged to complete an honors thesis as a further capstone experience.</p>
<p>The minor in Scandinavian is designed primarily for students who wish to undertake study of Nordic culture without learning a language. Except for communicative competence, the goals for the minor are the same as those for the major. The minor program does not include the capstone tutorials or the option of an honors thesis.</p>
<p>We observe the achievement of these goals in the post-B.A. career trajectories of our majors both in academic and a broad range of other professions that require these skills (rigorous training emphasizing language skills, research acumen, and persuasive argument): business, law, medicine, public policy and government, and the arts.</p>
<p><em>Paths to Learning Goals in the Scandinavian Major and Minor</em></p>
<p>Foundational courses:<br />
Scandin R5A, R5B (Reading and composition focusing on Nordic materials)<br />
Scandin 60 (Heroic Legends of the North)<br />
Scandin 75 (Literature and Culture of the Nordic World)</p>
<p>Linguistic Competence:<br />
Danish 1A-1B, Scandin 100A-100B (Scand. Languages and Linguistics; in Dan. section)<br />
Finnish 1A-1B, Finnish 102A-102B (Int. and Adv. Finnish; may be repeated for credit)<br />
Icelandic 1A-1B<br />
Norwegian 1A-1B, Scandin 100A-100B (Scand. Languages and Linguistics; in Norw. section)<br />
Swedish 1A-1B, Scandin 100A-B (Scand. Languages and Linguistics; in Swed. section)<br />
Scandin 101A-101B (Old Norse for undergraduates)</p>
<p>Literary Cultures and History:<br />
Scandin 123 (Viking and Medieval Scandinavia)<br />
Scandin 125 (Old Norse literature)<br />
Scandin 132 (Finnish Culture)<br />
Scandin 150 (Studies in Scandinavian literature. Subject varies; includes such period topics as Romanticism, Modern Breakthrough, and Decadence)<br />
Scandin C160 (Early Scandinavian myth and religion)</p>
<p>Canonical authors:<br />
Scandin 106 (H.C. Andersen)<br />
Scandin C107 (Ibsen)<br />
Scandin C108 (Strindberg)<br />
Scandin 115 (Studies in Drama and Film. Subject varies; includes Ingmar Bergman)</p>
<p>Genres:<br />
Scandin 115 (Studies in Drama and Film. Subject varies; includes Nordic directors; Cinema lighting; Silent film)<br />
Scandin 116 (Studies in Prose. Subject varies; includes such subjects as Isak Dinesen)<br />
Scandin 120 (The novel in Scandinavia)</p>
<p>Courses dealing with specific cross-disciplinary issues:<br />
Scandin C114 (Word and Image)<br />
Scandin 123 (Viking and Medieval Scandinavia)<br />
Scandin 150 (Studies in Scandinavian literature (subject varies; includes such topics as Nature and the City)</p>
<p>Study abroad:<br />
Many Scandinavian majors spend a summer, semester, or academic year at a university in a Nordic country, often through the Education Abroad Program, which has centers in Lund, Sweden, and Copenhagen, Denmark. We encourage such study as an excellent way to obtain the communicative and cultural competence that is the goal of our major.</p>
<p>Capstone experiences:<br />
Scandin 145 (Senior seminar)<br />
Scandin 149 (subject-oriented original language reading and writing)<br />
Senior thesis</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-595 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->

    		    		<script>
        jQuery(document).ready(function() {
           jQuery('.tooltip').tooltipster({
           	animation: 'fade',
   			delay: 200,

<article id="post-593" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Information for Transfer Students</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The Department of Scandinavian welcomes transfer students and encourages them to choose one of our five new major concentrations available beginning Fall Semester 2015. Our Undergraduate Student Services Advisor is available to help you plan course work towards a single major, but also for a double major or a minor. To find out about admission to Berkeley as a transfer student click <a href="http://admissions.berkeley.edu/transferstudents">here</a> for information.</p>
<p><strong>Good News for Community-College Transfer Students!</strong></p>
<p>You may have noticed by viewing transfer information offered by your community college that lower-division courses required for Scandinavian major concentrations are unavailable. This is due to the fact that Danish, Finnish, Norwegian, Swedish, and modern Icelandic are not commonly taught languages. The good news: students do not have to take language prerequisites and Scandinavian 60 and 75 before applying for transfer to be considered for admission to UC Berkeley and the major in Scandinavian. Our language sequences begin each Fall at both the first- and second-year levels, and the required lower-division courses Scandinavian 75 (Literature and Culture of the Nordic World, offered each Fall Semester) and 60 (Heroic Legends of the North, offered each Spring Semester) can be taken upon arrival and completed within the first academic year at Berkeley. The 46 total required units—including all upper-division requirements—can be completed within the four to five semesters allotted for transfer students to finish requirements for the Bachelor’s Degree.</p>
<p>If you are considering a major or double major, you should contact the Undergraduate Student Services Advisor as soon as possible after admission to Berkeley. The College of Letters and Science has a firm deadline for transfer students declaring a major (early in their second semester), so plan to start taking your first language course and Scandinavian 75 upon arrival in the fall. For information on requirements, click <a href="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/programs/undergraduate/major-and-minor/">here</a>.</p>
<p>If you plan to minor in Scandinavian, you should also contact our Undergraduate Student Services Advisor as early as possible to explore this option. For transfer students with a limited time to complete requirements for the Bachelor’s Degree, the sooner you explore this option the sooner we will be able to determine together whether adding a minor is workable. Students interested in the minor should plan a study list with an intent to minor with the Undergraduate Student Services Advisor. Click <a href="http://blogs.lscrtest.com/scandinavian/programs/undergraduate/major-and-minor/#minor">here</a> for information on requirements for the minor.</p>
<p><em>Who to Contact</em>:</p>
<p><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/people/amanda-minafo/">Amanda Minafo</a><br />
Undergraduate Student Services Advisor</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-593 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->

" alt=""></div>

<header id="site-header" class="home wideness" role="banner">
		<div class="upper-field">
		<a href="#">
			
			<div class="initial-quote">Þat eru bókrúnar, <br />
þat eru bjargrúnar,<br />
ok allar ǫlrúnar,<br />
ok mætar meginrúnar.</div>			
				<div class="mouse-over-quote">
					That is book-runes, <br />
that is birth-runes, <br />
and all ale-runes, <br />
and the famed power-runes.<br />
(Old Norse)				</div>
				
		
				<span class="quote-author"> - Sigrdrífumál, stanza 19</span>
				
			</a>
			
									 
	
	
	</div>
	
			<div class="site-header-content">
	 <h1><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu">  Major in Scandinavian</a></h1>
	 </div>
			<nav id="main-nav" role="navigation">
				<div class="menu-main-menu-container"><ul id="menu-main-menu" class="sf-menu"><li id="menu-item-1580" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-home menu-item-1580"><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/">Home</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1592" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1592"><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/news-and-events/">News &#038; Events</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1627" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page current-page-ancestor menu-item-has-children menu-item-1627"><a href="http://scandinavian.berkeley.edu/programs/undergraduate/">Programs</a>
